reviewText:
Talisman may not be the most complicated game around or hold a candle to the newer deck-builders or RPGs, but it holds a lot of nostalgia for me from my middle and high school days.  I thought a few bucks on a Steam game versus a much larger amount thrown at a random eBayer was wise, but unfortunately the game falls short.

It's buggy, especially in online play.  Two games were all it took to decide this is best played as a local match.  Freezes, CTDs, and the inability to drop in on an existing game really killed the experience.

Playing against CPUs is no fun, either.  The rolls always seem to go in their favor.  Don't believe me?  I finally had a good match and got to the Crown of Command, but it took over twenty turns to win because I rolled a 3 or lower about 75% of the time.  A game I would have won swiftly in real life turned into a Sorceress almost making her way to the Valley of Fire all the way from the Outer Region.

If you're nostalgic for the game and don't mind the extra cash, you'll be a lot happier with the game in hand.  This isn't a cheap alternative, in my opinion, because you're best off inviting your friends over to play anyway.

reviewText: This game is a great idea, but they have several rather serious issues, any one of which makes the game stupid.  As I said, the idea is great, so I'm saddened by the glaring flaws.\nFirst, and probably most importantly, this game is very nearly entirely luck.  Yes, you get to make 2 choices about where you land each turn.  2 choices.  If you use spells, you can decide who to cast them on.  But you don't get to decide what spells you have, or when you get them.  This game would be a bazillion times more fun if they added a speed stat that let you move any number of spaces less than or equal to your speed, instead of rolling the die.  One of my favorite cards is a follower that curses" you by making you only move 1 space each turn.  It gives me a unique sense of control in the game that I consider a major advantage.\nSecondly

reviewText:
I really like the board version of Talisman, so I snatched up this version on a Humble Bundle.  The game is fun, online or offline (but still better with friends).  If you like the board game, you'll probably like this version, as they did a good job getting the basic Talisman experience in here.  The UI can feel kind of awkward sometimes because of weird button placement and the need to click more times than necessary to do certain tasks, but it's possible to get used to and then it stops detracting from the game at all.  The game also has some advantages over the original such as not having to shuffle decks and manage pieces, and letting the computer do the combat math and automatically enforce the rules prevents any player from losing an encounter because they forgot to add an extra strength point from a follower that they lost in their inventory.   It's a more convenient way to play, in several regards.

That's why it's such a shame that the game is so buggy.  Sometimes the game breaks the rules in frustrating ways (spells targeting untargetable opponents, characters being unable to use abilities when they should be able to, cards that should only be used a limited number of times never disappearing from the board, etc.)  So far, every game I've played has had at least one bug that breached the rules.  They can be mildly amusing at best but game-breaking at worst.  The frequency of these bugs is the problem, as they wouldn't be much of an issue if it was just occasional.  But so far it's been every single game.

The bottom line is this: if you like Talisman, this is a pretty good version of it.  It gets all the content even if it lacks some of the streamlining it could have.  However, the frequent bugs are frustrating and having a bug break your game 90 minutes in is enough to make you not want to play again.  If the developers could take care of the bugs, I would definitely recommend getting this game.  Unfortunately, I'd now only recommend getting it on sale.

reviewText:
Great start to a great classic game. I've been an owner of multiple versions of Talisman over the years and was very exicted to see this being worked on. While it has some bugs and annoyances, overall I think it's a great start. I'll go over some of the issues first.

1) Random crashes. Yeah , they happen. Hopefully they clear up before it goes live as this completely ruins a live game.
2) Bad network connectivity. People randomly just disconnect. Whats worse, is there is no way to re-join a game (that I am aware of) to continue. AI takes over.
3) Spell casting is not intuitive. I played for over a month until i realized I can queue up a spell to automatically cast on the next players start of turn. Casting counter spell at the right time seems rough. The general responsiveness of double clicking spells is bad. Sometimes you have to click 20 times for it to actually work.
4) No way to stop zooming into the board. This might be good for most people are a new to the game, but veterans dont need to read the board every time and would rather keep an overall look of the board. They need to make this an option.

Other than these three issues, the game is great. The rules are handled very well, I have only found one or two issues I have had to report on rules. The animations dont overbear the game. The speed of turns is just right, with included features like auto-kill when there is no need to roll opposing dice.

One feature i'd like to see is allowing AI to play your turn for you while you take a bathroom break :)

reviewerDisplayName: Together we saw the end in sight
reviewText:
+: Talisman is a recreation of the famous board game Talisman on PC with online multiplayer for up to 4 players. If you don't know what Talisman is I'll sum it up real quick: turn based brain dead easy to play fantasy RPG inspired board game that revolves around basically 99% luck. Skill does matter to a degree, but you can and will get completely destroyed by unlucky dice rolls again, and again, and again, and again. This is not a competitive skill based game and it is highly recommended you play it when you are drunk/high/give no ♥♥♥♥s otherwise your friends will get mad at you when all their dice rolls are going great and then you proceed to steal all their stuff and win while doing absolutely nothing other than steal all their stuff.
+: The game is mostly stable after several updates and performs great although it'd be impressive if it didn't considering it's a simplistic game.
+: The DLC works similar to PAYDAY 2 where if one person has it everyone in the same game as that person also has it except for the character classes.
-: If you buy this game even though you hate luck based game you're gonna have a bad time.
-: Games do take a long amount of time, upwards of 4+ hours at times. Especially with the expansions on.
-: The expansion DLCs come out so slow. :(
voteText: 1 person found this review helpful 1 person found this review funny

reviewText: This is a very good way to test Talisman out and see if you like it before purchasing it as a board game. The physical game is more expensive, especially if you end up buying all the other characters and expansions, so I would definitely suggest buying everything on steam and testing it all out to see what you like and don't like. It is also makes the rules very clear opposed to the physical copy, which makes you guess at some rules because of wording. All in all, I would suggest getting this game if you are at all interested in buying the physcal version. You may even like this version more, as you can always join tables online if you want to play but your friends are unavailable. It is sometimes buggy and won't load characters the first time you start it up and friends join, but that problem goes away the second time you start the game. I own both the physcial and PC version of this game, and though I prefer the physcial board game, I do enjoy this thoroughly.

reviewText:
After putting +100 hours in this game, i decided to write my first review, to hopefully raise awareness to this amazing tabletop.

Talisman is great for fantasy lovers and offers lots of diferent heros with different abilities to play as, which is one of my favourite features in a game. All the heros are fun, some more powerful than others, but every one of them can win if you manage to use its abilities to its full potential.

Although there is some skill involved in this game, most of the player's performance is driven by luck. Preety much all actions (movement, combat, encounters) are defined/influenced by the dice rolls. This means that no matter how experienced you are, you can get destroyed by a noob who installed the game 10 minutes prier, which can be frustrating at times.

Another thing worth noting is that there are lots of possibilities for turning the tide in the middle of the game. This means that even if you're losing completely and the other players have much better stats than you, theres always a chance one of them will suddenly turn into a toad (and therefore leaving all objects/followers available to pickup) and allowing you to get all his stuff. Or maybe someone is about to enter the Crown of Comand (the place you need to reach to win the game) and you cast a spell on them and force him to loose his Talisman, the one object that allows them to get there. This triggers a lot of people, but i personally think it adds a lot to the game, and even though this stuff has happened to me numerous times, i end up having a laugh about it because at the end of the day, the game is fun. Just note that there's never a guaranteed win/loss, and you can always hope for a comeback or fear your demise!

Expansions make the game a whole lot better, and the more you have, the more varied the game becomes and the more ways there are to make your way up to the top!

Pros:
-Lots of fun with friends
-Wide variety of heros
-Playable on a toaster
-Great to play at work (Tab in when it's your turn)
-Unpredictable
-Amazing when you have access to expansions
-You dont have to purchase all the expansions in order to enjoy them provided that you play online with a player that owns them!

Cons:
-Very luck driven
-Games are super long
-Not as enjoyable if you dont have access to expansions

reviewText:
A great adaptation of the physical board game, and then some.

Additional house rules available, plenty of character variety, true-to-the-original game play, and adequate production values make it a great digital version of the physical game.

I find overall its somewhat expensive, with extra characters costing 2 dollars each and mini-expansions 6.  The season pass is 60 bucks and is supposed to offer a savings so, that gives you an idea of the price of DLC.

I LOATHE the spell system though, it needed to be done differently. More often than not any 'questionable' spells (ie ones that play during others turns or counterspells) often result in mistakes or missed opportunities.  I definitely consider this a con.

Overprices and terrible spell system aside, any fan of the board game should be nothing short of pleased with the digital version.  Though, perhaps finding it on sale would be wise.

I'd give it a 7/10.  Its true talisman. But its also games workshop, hence its over priced.

reviewText:
This game is amazing. I had never played the boardgame and went blind into this one, together with 3 other people. We imidiately spent 9-10 hours into this game. The first game we played just vanila to get to know how the game works. It was quite fun already. After that we added the expansions and the game just got even better! The game can drag on quite a bit due to it's RNG... but it's the fun type of RNG, so that's totally okay!

The goal of the game is simple. You must be the first one to reach the middle. In the vanila version, you have the crown of command there, which will do damage to each other character 50% of the times (based on a d6 roll). Characters normaly respawn/get rerolled when they die, but not when someone is in the middle. If one player is left on the board, they win.

The game features quite a lot of characters to choose from. They all have their own set of stats, aswell as a set of special abilities of which some are shared, while others are unique. The most fun way to play, though, is that everyone starts with a random character and upon death they get a new, random character! During the game you will encounter many different kinds of events, monsters and items. The more expansions you have, the more random and sometimes deadly the game becomes.

I would say, if you aren't sure about buying this one. First buy the vanila version only. Once you know if you'll like it, feel free to buy the rest of the DLC, they're all worth it. Though you do not need the Runestone Deck DLC, you can unlock these ingame as far as I know.

Edit: The runestones basicly give you boosts to your character: you can start with more in a stat or you can more easily upgrade your character and so forth. They seem to be designed for those who want a game that'll end more swiftly. Personally I'd suggest to play without these, unless everyone has them and you want your game to end sooner.

reviewText:
First, let me say that I've only played this solo and know nothing about the multiplayer functionality.

There seems to be something really wrong with the random number generator in this game. When making choices, you often have to consider the odds of an awful thing happening. Yet, even when the ONLY way something bad can happen is if I roll two 1's in a row, that's what WILL happen... and it doesn't happen infrequently. It happens over and over and over again. I've only EVER been able to get into the middle track once and no matter what character I play, the computer controlled players get nearly all good luck and I get nearly all bad luck. Frankly, it doesn't even feel like luck. It feels like the computer is actively controlling the dice rolls so it can hose me.

The game itself had ample opportunity to be enhanced graphically for a computer via animated cards and board and combat, but the developers chose to not do anything but reproduce the board and the cards exactly as they would appear when playing around a table. As a result, the computer game feels lifeless and utterly uninspired. Why not use the computer to do something the board game can't with some effects and such? The answer to that question is a mystery.

The user interface is simply horrible. Every moment of every turn is stretched out into a laborious sequence of moving and clicking. The game control elements are spread out all over the screen, so you have to move the mouse from one end of the screen to the other whenever an option is presented, rather than keeping the interface elements near one another so they are easy to use.

Others have reported a plethora of bugs. I can't say I've really encountered any, but then I've never actually played much beyond the beginning of any game. My 'luck' is SO bad that I can barely get started before I'm so far behind that catching up is impossible. It isn't much fun to continue playing when losing is a foregone conclusion, so I end up quitting to play something that is actually fun.

reviewText:
A must have for any true board game fan. Its also great fun and probally without this game's idea's you could forget most of those great warhammer games, skyrim, baldurs gate and kiss them all goodbye.

Update: 23 September 2014.

Considering the games time of release, the frequent bugs, latency issues and eagerness to release downloadable content (individual character cards which are not actually offical board game game cards. Whilst not addressing bug issues first, has resulted in compounding errors/crashes due to adding cards from introduced cards from the expansions that have not been coded properly to new merge abilties for example with older ones.

Update 2/12/2014

Since the Dungeon Expansion...

I recommend this game now on the basis the decks are a lot better, the new board and characters are amazing. A lot of bugs have been fixed (still a few kicking around). House rules implimented including the standard character" rule for true fans who do not wish for the overpriced $2 dlc cards pay to win implimented.

Another great feature is now you can add and remove players while in lobby instead of totally rehosting. I would recommend buying this

reviewText:
Talisman has always tended to polarise opinion in board game circles.  It is often critisized for being overly dependent on luck at the expense of strategy by those who deride such types of games.  I like to refer to it as fantasy Monopoly, where instead of property you go around collecting objects and followers (and battle enemy monsters and players) until you're powerful enough to win the game.

Despite its detractors, Talisman has maintained a passionate, loyal and extremely devoted following.  Like Monopoly, its appeal lies in its simple, light-hearted and accessible nature that isn't complicated, difficult or overly strategic.  In other words, the very things it is criticised for.  That's not to say there aren't strategic elements but they're certainly not dominant.  It's a game you can wistfullly play while the hours pass by (and I do mean hours) without thinking too much.  If that's not to your liking, there are plenty of other more serious games to consider.

Talisman benefits enormously from the digital transition which has been implemented fairly well, with some exceptions.  Most notably are occasional bugged rules and weak AI players, but these don't detract too much from the enjoyment of the game.  I was pleasently surprised by the friendliness of online players also.

If you appreciate light-hearted and fun games that anyone can pick up or enjoy board games with great artwork on the board and the cards then I can highly recomment Talisman.  I have over 100 hours logged so far and I find it's a great (and addictive) distraction and great to take your mind off things.

I should note that the base game is a little bare and Talisman benefits when played with some of the expansions.  The season pass is also fairly pricey, but I got it on sale so I think it's good value if you can wait until a sale.  Given the number of characters and expansions I can't recommend buying them separetely.  You really have to go all in and get the season pass if you want the extra content.  It's not worth buying expansions in dribs and drabsm but if you had to I'd say Reaper, Frostmarch and Sacred Pool are recommended first because they don't add extra boards (regions) that chcange the game a bit.

reviewText: Talisman's first edition, with many of its expansions, ate up a lot of my time as a regular board game. This digital edition includes both classic rules and new edition rules, plus many more expansions are coming out. They're ironing out details of the main game now, the Reaper expansion is out, and many characters are available to play. This game can be played single player against one or several computer opponents, or it can be played online. I haven't tried the online play because I'm too chicken and get interrupted a lot, but it looks like a lot of time and effort is being put in by the developers to polish it up. The game itself is pretty, simple to control, and all the fun I remember, except for smack talk when dealing with AI opponents.

reviewText:
This is a digital version of Talisman. If you've played the board game, you more or less know what to expect.  It even supports 4 local players and some common house rules.

Advantages of the digital version:
-Cheaper: even without a Steam sale, you can buy the Gold Pack which is basically the same as buying the board game and EVERY expansion, for closer to the price of the board game and a single expansion.

-Portability: It's easier to carry around a laptop than several boxes.

-Easy to setup and cleanup

-Solo play: if you can't get a game night going, you can play with up to three AI players.

-Online play: Play with your friends online.  Or play with strangers.  Whatever floats your boat.

-New characters that I don't recall being in the board game

Disadvantages of the Digital Edition

-New characters are DLC

-4 player only (my gaming group is 5)

-Sometimes it's harder to see what's on the board or your inventory when it's not laid out in front of you.

On the whole, if you're  a fan of the board game, I highly recommend the Digital Edition.

reviewText: It's astonishing how boring and badly designed Talisman is. I've played the tabletop version of Talisman before and always thought it was an awful game. I love board games, have dozens of them, but Talisman... It takes the features of games like Monopoly and other trail games and try to entice you with a mildly interesting (though generic) fantasy setting, but the truth is it remains as boring, flawed and outdated as Monopoly itself.\n\nThe game may drag for hours and hours without an ending in sight and everything is about randomness. There's no skill involved playing in Talisman, all you can do push your luck in a general direction and hope for the best. I understand why a game like this would be popular 20 or 30 years ago, but today we have plenty of better board (and digital) games to play. Maybe *huge* fans of Mario Party would enjoy playing digital Talisman, but I just can't recommend it to anyone else. You want to play digital board games" on Steam? Grab "Small World 2"

reviewText:
They've had a long time to fix many of the bugs and they haven't. I was pretty patient about it, I faithfully reported bugs when I saw them and waited months but rather than fix the old content they kept shoveling out new content. Making Android and Itunes adaptions and adding the expansion with a half ♥♥♥♥♥ game production.


The UI is terrible, it places the “accept” and “drop” button as close as possible to each other making it very easy to misclick. It lacks any sense of forethought or planning.

The AI is a roomba bot gone rogue. It attacks the same players over and over even though it will obviously lose. It has almost no sense for self preservation and almost always dies. Or it cheats when it gets certain objects like the magic carpet and rolls 6's non stop.

The games had so many bugs from the beginning the developers have failed to either realize themselves or fix themselves. If they needed more money than they should have made the game advertisement supported with a paid option for people who didn't want the ads. This would have brought in a larger player base and gave people the chance to try it out. They also could have given the starting game for free and then sold the expansion and characters for more.

The general stability of the game is terrible, it crashes so often, that games frequently have to be resumed. Resume is the one saving grace of this game but in spite of all of that, the general incompetence of the developers ruins what could otherwise be a wonderful game.

I can't recommend this game to anyone until the developers stop shoveling new content and fix what they have now.
voteText: 4 of 7 people (57%) found this review helpful

reviewText:
Adventure board game relying strongly on luck. Clunky UI makes playing a harsh experience. Others mentioned that this was a mobile port and it shows. Settings are limited and it will reset some of the options every time you restart the game. Some features, like speeding up or skipping animations are not available, which tends to drag games even longer than required.

Has some technical issues. With nearly 10 hours gametime, there has been couple crashes. Also, one friend kept having connection issues for unknown reason. Luckily, the session can be restored but it still requires extra time. Cashing on too many DLCs and extra junk that could have been easily bundled in bigger packages. Luckily, only the server has to buy them so that others can play with additional content. Some of the characters are much stronger than others which brings balancing issues.

Core game mechanic relies too heavily on dice, especially in the early game. As most of the actions are ruled by the dice, one can find hero facing only dragons, giants and ogres with their two point strength weakling. This results in frustration as the player cannot really do anything except pray for better luck. Situation becomes ever worse with the DLCs as they bring even more monsters which makes encounters even more random. Core game could use separate decks for outer and middle regions. This way outer region could give more certain, but slow, early progress and middle region faster but more risky way.

Usually some of the players get lucky in the early game and snowball out of control. When hero gets enough resources, they start to win battles automatically which makes them even stronger. Single game can easily last two hours as the early winning players makes certain that they are unbeatable until finishing the game.

Summary: technically shoddy and somewhat lacking playing experience. Can be fun with friends. Recommended only for Talisman fanatics. Others should avoid or enjoy the life as a toad.

reviewText: Seems to rely on loaded dice to provide a challenge as opposed to any sort of competent and forward thinking AI.  But if you don't mind that, it's not a bad game.  Believe the devs when they say the dice don't cheat?  You cannot convince me.  Here is just one tale of one game I played:\n\nYes, I have read that they claim all dice rolls are generated before the game even starts and the order doesn't change, ie no cheating dice.  I call BS.  Pushed my way to the crown and suddenly of the 3 AI players, 2 start doing everything they can to help/save the 4th.  The fourth starts making amazing rolls and I realize I'm only getting above a 3 one in seven rolls.  Amazing given it should be roughly 50/50 chance.  But for 40 rolls I only get 6 above a 3.  Because the other 2 AI were even using their healing spells on the 4th that means it was down to me and that 4th AI.  He bounces around the board always managing to land any time I get manage to get his health down by 2, collect 7 followers, 7 items, crazy stats, and heads for the portal that's been up since the start of the game.  About this time I get him down to 1 health and think, Surely
date: this must be almost over."  Two rounds later he gets to the portal and of course rolls a 6 putting him in the Plains near the end.  Three rounds later he has rolled a 1 at the vampire and a 1 at the Pitfiends.  He's still at 1 health and I've now rolled 7 times less than a 4.  He keeps coming and I keep failing to roll above a 3.  Right before he gets to the crown I manage to roll a 6 and take him out.  The game sustained a 1 in 7 chance of rolling a 4
hoursPlayed: or 6 on a six sided die for an hour.  Just me clicking "next" cause once you get to the crown there's nothing else you can do.  Exciting.  That was just one game.  Will not play again.  Do not recommend."

reviewText: This game is a good representation of board game, but unless you're playing locally with friends, it's just not worth it.\n\nI have a perpetual game going with one other AI player.  I'm sitting at the crown of command, where you need to roll a 4,5, or 6 to deal 1 point of damage to all other players.  The goal is to finish off the other players either before they reach the crown or just to finish the game.  The problem is that even when you happen to roll high enough to deal damage, the AI runs around the outside of the board and finds ways to heal themselves.  The AI has no interest in progressing to the crown and unless the random" number generator allows me to roll high enough times in a row

reviewText:
Talisman is a faithful digital re-creation of the board game I played and loved as a teen.

However, as with most board game conversions, it really loses somthing when playing on a computer. It's just not much fun without a crowd of friends huddled around the table.

Recommended for fans of the original who want to relive the past, but not for new players. If you've never played Talisman, I recommend the board game, but not the computer version.

reviewText:
About 2 years ago (mid-2013), Talisman Prologue introduced me to Talisman on Android, and i thoroughly enjoyed it. When Talisman came out, i did not hesitate to get it and have not stopped playing it since. i only got Steam Talisman working in a Windows VM today, so Steam still rates me as a Noobite, but i've got well over 200 Talisman sessions behind me on Android. It is a near-perfect rendition of the board game (which i have also bought since becoming a fan). Many consider it to be too random, but the fact is that it holds a lot of strategy (part of which is dealing with the randomness). Talisman is _easily_ my most-played Android game, and now that Steam works on my desktop machine (via a Windows VM), it will certainly become my most-played non-Android/non-Linux game as well.

If any notable degree of randomness just makes you angry, don't try Talisman, but if you're looking for a lighthearted beer-and-pretzels style fantasy romp, Talisman might just fit the bill in epic form.

Tip for new players: PLEASE, FOR THE LOVE OF GOD, LEARN THE GAME IN SOLO MODE BEFORE PLAYING ONLINE!!!! Few things are more frustrating in online play than having to wait for new players to read every single card and every single square every single turn. So please, for the love of your fellow players, play it solo _AT LEAST 50 TIMES_ before playing online. Learn 90%+ of the cards and board spaces by heart. Your fellow players will appreciate it and will stop dropping out of games which you cause to drag on for 2 hours longer than necessary because you didn't do your homework before playing. Please. Thank you.

reviewText:
I spent 10 hours playing 2 matches (versus 3x AI, at speed 4).

Cons:
-There are meaningful decisions to be made, but they are dwarfed by RNG.
-It therefore follows that hours of building up can be undone in seconds.
-Once a player makes it to the Crown, it seems there is little that can be done.
-Matches take a very long time if you see them all the way through.
-Clunky magic system. It would be much better if every player was asked to pass, rather than give 5 seconds to cast.
-Bit buggy? Sometimes mechanics are not applied [correctly]?

Pros:
-...I spent 10 hours playing 2 matches. Clearly, despite the cons, this is just fun for me on some bizarre, torturous level!
voteText: 1 of 2 people (50%) found this review helpful 1 person found this review funny

reviewText:
There's no satisfaction in winning or losing as the entire game (except for the spells aspect) is based 100% on luck. I'd never thought I'd find a game based more on luck than Monopoly, but here it is. If you like to strategize then this game is not for you, your ability to reach the end and win is purely determined by dice rolls and luck of draw cards (all dice rolls are pre-calculated before the game starts).

No strategy will overcome events like being turned into a toad 7 times within 8 turns (yes this did happen) or losing a fight with a 60/50 chance of winning 13 times in a row (yes this happened too).

Talisman is really just a dice simulator with music and ren fair style graphics, and just ended up in my uninstall pile.
voteText: 4 of 8 people (50%) found this review helpful 1 person found this review funny

reviewText:
After other players managed to convince me the constant crashes are due to a recent expansion and the Devs are usually on top of it with fixes, I realised that it was the hand of fate that made me start this game in the middle of utter chaos.

Thus, on the basis of the game alone, I give it my thumbs up
(changed from negative).

Yes, the game itself, when not crashing, is fun.
Well, for people with stamina and patience and time for a bit of commitment it is fun,
for people that like the intimacy of boardgames it is fun,
I do not recommend it for impatient kids that can't sit still for 15 minutes, because fun will not be had.

Is it worth the money the expansion sets cost?
That is something everyone needs to decide for themselves, in comparison I'd say it's not too steep
(although I'm tight enough to have weighed these words before typing them).
All in all, (and I'm liking it more every time I play a game without crashing),
I give the game a careful 6.7 out of 10.

Please take my playing time into account, which isn't very long, check the reviews of those who have been playing it for longer, or you know, take the plunge!

Greetings fellow travellores and connaisseurs of Trollplaying games (TPG's)

reviewText:
Talisman: Digital Edition은 1~6인용 보드게임 Talisman 4판을 Nomad Games Limited에서 PC 및 휴대기기용으로 제작한 1~4인용 게임입니다. 일전에 이에 앞서 유료데모로 내놓는 만행을 벌였던 Talisman: Prologue에 대해서 리뷰( http://etude87.tistory.com/97 )한 적이 있는데 그것의 완성판으로 2014년 2월 26일에 출시되었습니다.

PC 이식 및 네트워크 멀티플레이를 지원한다는 장점이 있으나 멍청한 A.I와 기본 구조적 한계 그리고 각종 멀티플레이를 저어하게 만드는 요소들로 인해 Talisman: Digital Edition은 싹수부터 노랗다는 것을 다시 한번 증명했습니다. 타인에게 썩 추천하고 싶지 않습니다만 비교적 저렴한 가격과 휴대용 기기용으로도 많이 나왔으니 친구들과 모여서 보드게임 하고 싶을 때 실물 대신 사용하는 정도로는 쓸모가 있을 것입니다. 더 자세한 내용은 블로그 포스트( http://etude87.tistory.com/179 )를 참고.

ps. 최근 시즌패스 내용물 관련해서 차후 추가될 모든 컨텐츠 제공이란 문구를 수정하고 열번째 캐릭터팩을 시즌패스 적용외 물품으로 내놓으면서 커뮤니티 허브에서도 말이 많아진 상태입니다.

reviewText:
Trying this on the free play weekend. 9 hours, 3 playthroughs against 3 AI opponents.
The good:
- addictive gameplay - would play with friends
- content? (DLC, yeah...)
The bad:
- late game phases can get slow, even on max AI speed
- BUGS. I had to kill the game on 2 different occassions, one of them being a crash to desktop. On another, a card effect (reduces movement to 1) got stuck on me despite the AI having and then discarding the actual card. Ended up quitting that game too. The game also loses fullscreen mode on each Alt-Tab.

As is, I might still grab the main game on sale. No DLC though - I wouldn't want to support game devs who prioritise DLCs over fixing major bugs.

reviewText:
Talisman the board game in digital version.

Theres no point reviewing the talisman itself,its a dice board game.you toss the die,move and stuff happens.

However reviewing the digital content of this board game.

Pros:
-You dont need friends to play and you dont need to play all the characters alone if you wanna play
-AI seems allright
-Easy to change rules

Cons
-Bugs bugs and bugs. i played more than hour in 4 player game online,so far we were all at outer and one player casted spell. it crashed the game completely. there was noway going back anymore. that shouldnt happen,if that happens you simply dont release the game. there is no price on good game and that lost hour.

after you get over that the game was lost you simply think,should i start new game what if it crashes again after hours of playing? these things should not happen in game like this,never. And this isnt first and last game breaking bug sometimes game forces you to do something because it jams every other option.

If they fix the bugs ill give this port 9/10 (9 cause it could look more pretty) and recommend it but until then 4/10 cause of the bugs in this game.

reviewText: Having played this game a few times now, I've so far encountered: an idiotic AI that doesn't attempt to reach the crown of command, required to win the game, despite having near-max stats.  An AI that will move a single space every turn due to a poltergeist, healing each turn and therefore causing a stalemate, causing me to lose out on XP and achievement progress.  And most recently, an AI that on the brink of a loss decides to constantly check his inventory on an infinite loop, disallowing me my final turn like the worst of poor losers.  Having experienced all this with just 4.7 hours on record shows what a terrible game this is, in terms of AI, bugs, and problems with the game system in general.\nMay still try the online mode as friends have bought the game, but if playing against the AI just give up now.  Either you won't be allowed to win, or it will be a hollow victory.

reviewText:
Sadly this game is NOT worth playing.  Its a great Idea and could have been a lot of fun.  I played a full round against the ai a round with players and a mixed round.

Pros:
Great Idea
Looks cool.
I love board games.
It has some really interesting abilities and cards.

Cons:
The AI is HORRIBLE!
Turns take far to long even at speed 10.
Horrible Networking, I couldn't see games and had to have my friends invite me. We played for a while and then one of us couldn't do anything and it just sat there, so we reloaded and now only I could see the network games and had to invite everyone else. Also the method of resuming an online game is... an afterthought.
Buggy, we ran into many crashes , cards would not cast at the end of your turn like they said even though they were qued, amoung many other incorrect spell castings.
Dissapointing end game, just standing on the crown rolling 1 die every round with no option of leaving or backtracking, not sure who thought that up but it was bad. Players could just sit there and pelt you with spells build up there stats  and then kill you.
Total dissapointment.
The Music was uninspired.
The price, $79.99 for the complete version, I won't ever play this again even if its free.

reviewText: First off, let me say that the actual gameplay is pretty fun, especially when playing with friends online. The game can get very cut-throat and you will enjoy lots of laughs at the expese of other player's misfortune. The expansions make the game even more enjoyable and there are different game rules available that can make the game more exciting. If I was recommending this on the gameplay alone, I would definitely give it a great review.\n\nThat being said, this game is TERRIBLE when it comes to programming. It is full of game-stopping glitches that should have been weeded out during development. Nothing is more frustrating than to be two hours into a highly competitive and exciting game, only to have it RUINED by a glitch that will not allow the game to contine. The matchmaking is shotty at best, and the lack of a save feature to save and resume multiple games outside of the single automatic game save really gets on your nerves. This game is not worth buying unless GW fixes the bugs that are killing this game.

reviewText:
Ok, first of all there is no decent tutorial and the link to the rules leads you to an  extensive site full of text. First play I stayed completely lost in the game for several turns, the cards were showing up too fast and I had no idea of what was going on.

After understanding a little of what was going on I tryed to play with random AI characters. I lost 3 encounters in a row on the first 3 tutns and died, while the AI got several followers and Items. Just a bad experience, ok I rage quit and restart.

Second go: Oponent first turns rolls to other side of the river, flips 3 cards gets 7 gold. My first turn Dragon. Another bad experience, ok...

Third try I realized I could set AI speed, I realized I could pause the game and check on the cards, but I still dont know where the buffs and debuffs are coming from, I loose battle even though I win battles, a guy fights me with 2 strenght and suddenly he has 8 strenght. I lost 3 turns in a row, frogged, one of my oponents has talisman, belt of strenght, solomons crown and a unicorn, I died once, got lost in cave and lost all my gold gambling.

Long story short, I played the game times, never drew an equipment,the only follower i had was a hag and I died several times, while having no tooltips hints or decent tutorial, it took me an hour to realize my re-rolls were consuming fate counters and I couldn't understanding why it was not working anymore. I rage quit all of the games I started.

Some my say it was just a bad luck or the game is hard, I see it as a very very bad experience that was worsen by the fact that the game leaves you in the dark.

I still don't know what trophies are for, ehat happens when you fight a player, what's the point of capturing a wolf as follower and what or where is the chasm.

[UPDATE]

Just found out the dice rolls are rigged, no matter how many times I load the game on the same save spot, the dice results for ALL the rolls are the same, even the fate re-rolls are the sam. This was the most frustrating discovery so far. I don't know if there is a reason for that, or they just couldn't design an easy and simple dice roll algorithm.

reviewText: I never got into the talisman board game while growing up but wanted to give it a try. The game drags on and on forever and is entirely too random about when and how you get screwed over. reviewText: A surprisingly charming and enjoyable throwback ruined by one completely fatal flaw: Matches can take well over an hour, even two hours with four players taking time to actually enjoy the game at a reasonable pace, and there is no meaningful pause or save feature in multiplayer. There is a hard coded timer you cannot disable, where if you are AFK for 5 minutes, the CPU instantly takes your turn for you, often making rather poor choices. Matches lose their luster when you realize you're locked into an endurance match and if you get up to do anything more involved than grabbing a drink, you'd better pray you're quick about it.\n\nIt's a terrible shame, because it really is an enjoyable game that aside. But once you start playing, God help you if you want to take a break. This egregious oversight sort of destroys everything for what's supposed to be a computerized version of a BOARD GAME.
voteText: 4 of 8 people (50%) found this review helpful

reviewText: This game is a giant waste of time. It could have been great but with brain dead AI and the game actively cheating to make you lose to make up for the unimaginably stupid AI it boils down to an extremely boring slog. I even reached the center only for the game to drag on for another two hours as the AI was too dumb to reach the center and fight me while I rolled less than 4 several times in a row interspaced by one or two times rolling high enough to do damage only for the enemy to miraculously roll the exact number to land on a healing spot over and over and over again. The only reason I won is because they managed to damage themselves to the point where I could kill them with 1 lucky roll. I should be paid for having to suffer through that crap. My recommendation stay away setting the money that could be spent on this game on fire would be a more worthwhile investment and this game.

reviewText: This game is frustrating and not fun.

reviewText:
Ok, first of all there is no decent tutorial and the link to the rules leads you to an  extensive site full of text. First play I stayed completely lost in the game for several turns, the cards were showing up too fast and I had no idea of what was going on.

After understanding a little of what was going on I tryed to play with random AI characters. I lost 3 encounters in a row on the first 3 tutns and died, while the AI got several followers and Items. Just a bad experience, ok I rage quit and restart.

Second go: Oponent first turns rolls to other side of the river, flips 3 cards gets 7 gold. My first turn Dragon. Another bad experience, ok...

Third try I realized I could set AI speed, I realized I could pause the game and check on the cards, but I still dont know where the buffs and debuffs are coming from, I loose battle even though I win battles, a guy fights me with 2 strenght and suddenly he has 8 strenght. I lost 3 turns in a row, frogged, one of my oponents has talisman, belt of strenght, solomons crown and a unicorn, I died once, got lost in cave and lost all my gold gambling.

Long story short, I played the game times, never drew an equipment,the only follower i had was a hag and I died several times, while having no tooltips hints or decent tutorial, it took me an hour to realize my re-rolls were consuming fate counters and I couldn't understanding why it was not working anymore. I rage quit all of the games I started.

Some my say it was just a bad luck or the game is hard, I see it as a very very bad experience that was worsen by the fact that the game leaves you in the dark.

I still don't know what trophies are for, ehat happens when you fight a player, what's the point of capturing a wolf as follower and what or where is the chasm.

[UPDATE]

Just found out the dice rolls are rigged, no matter how many times I load the game on the same save spot, the dice results for ALL the rolls are the same, even the fate re-rolls are the sam. This was the most frustrating discovery so far. I don't know if there is a reason for that, or they just couldn't design an easy and simple dice roll algorithm.

reviewText:
For those who can't get to an actual table often (or at all) this is a great alternative to play Talisman.  Don't know what it is?  Think Fantasy Monopoly and you sort of have the idea, only instead of buying properties and gathering cash and boning your friends, you're fighting monsters, gathering treasure, gambling money, and... well, boning your friends.  It's an all-time classic board game.

Only downside is they charge about the same amount for the DLC as they do for the real game's expansions, so if you actually can get a good regular gaming group together, getting the actual game is probably a much better course of action for you.

Note: as of this writing, the DLC list has shrunk down to three, so the above comment may no longer be valid, but during the Early Access, you could see listed all the expansions for the physical game at the same price.  This may turn up later.

EDIT: Don't know why my play counter is 0.  I've definitely played this a helluvalot more than that.

reviewText: First off, let me say that the actual gameplay is pretty fun, especially when playing with friends online. The game can get very cut-throat and you will enjoy lots of laughs at the expese of other player's misfortune. The expansions make the game even more enjoyable and there are different game rules available that can make the game more exciting. If I was recommending this on the gameplay alone, I would definitely give it a great review.\n\nThat being said, this game is TERRIBLE when it comes to programming. It is full of game-stopping glitches that should have been weeded out during development. Nothing is more frustrating than to be two hours into a highly competitive and exciting game, only to have it RUINED by a glitch that will not allow the game to contine. The matchmaking is shotty at best, and the lack of a save feature to save and resume multiple games outside of the single automatic game save really gets on your nerves. This game is not worth buying unless GW fixes the bugs that are killing this game.

reviewText:
Bought a four pack for my friends and me for 4€ not expecting much, we were simply blown away after 2 games and have at least played 5 rounds for every week since the initial purchase.

I highly recommend buying the season pass (includes all future expansions and characters except the shaman, which i glady payed for since the money spent is given to a charity) to add more depth to the otherwise limited standard game.

Pros:
- ideal game for four people
- beautiful visual presentation of the original board game
- the game never gets boring (even after 136h)
- lots of different characters with different abilities and properties (for starters i recommend randomizing your char pick)
- multiple endings

minor cons:
- avoid playing on a weekend where the game is free to play (seriously it is unplayable in mp)
- the spell system could use a little overhaul
- more game options ( for example choosing which endings can occur and which can not)

Overall i would give this game a 9.9 of 10

reviewText:
DO NOT BUY.

I just lost my first game of this because the spell Healing didn't have any effect on me when it should've right at the end of the game. I also noticed other spells not actually having their effect trigger occasionally when they should. The spell Random was particularly bad for this, with AI opponents it was used on not even rolling for the effect sometimes (seems to be a problem particularly when someone is on the Crown of Command).

The interface in this game needs work (sometimes you don't know what spell you're currently casting, or what type of card it wants you to select from where).

It's generally pretty fun, but I simply can't play it while it doesn't abide by its own rules.

reviewText: I really want to like this game, because board games rule, but wow the game this is based on is absolutely garbage.  This plays like monopoly with an RPG element.  It's ridiculously random - a ton of the locations give huge awards for rolling 4-6 and huge penalties for rolling 1-3.  Movement itself is largely based on rolls (unless you, again, are lucky and find a teleport spell/event) so you can't even move around with strategy.  You just go where it tells you, deal with whatever good/bad thing that happens, then wait for your next turn.\n\nNot only is the gameplay horrendous, but it's littered with reminders to purchase tons of overpriced DLC.  Base game for $1, DLC for $30?  No thanks.  Don't buy this.
voteText: 3 of 6 people (50%) found this review helpful

reviewText:
Do you love boardgames? Do you own boardgames? Do you play them with your friends (hopefully!)? Than this game CAN definatly be for you. But it also depends on how much nostalgia you feel for Talisman. Us boardgamers in general probably wont like this game, it takes a lot of time (can take up to 3 hours), your actions are ALMOST completley random thanks to dicerolling. And you also lose the feeling of moving components around on a board which is a huge part of the enjoyment for this game.

If you're a not a boardgamer I would recomend that you stay away from this game. It probably wont meet up with any (if any) of your expectations. This game can be fun with a few friends but you will probably end up only playing a single game of it before moving on to some other game or you know... any other REAL boardgame.

Talisman in general is sadly not a great boardgame nomatter how much nostalgia you feel for it.
It's basicly a more nerdy version of Monopoly which is the worst... boardgame... ever. Instead of getting this get the game for your pads so that you can play it on long trips on a buss, train, car (unless you're driving) and plane. But make sure you have some people to play with even then.

/ Nurgleprobe

reviewText:
After other players managed to convince me the constant crashes are due to a recent expansion and the Devs are usually on top of it with fixes, I realised that it was the hand of fate that made me start this game in the middle of utter chaos.

Thus, on the basis of the game alone, I give it my thumbs up
(changed from negative).

Yes, the game itself, when not crashing, is fun.
Well, for people with stamina and patience and time for a bit of commitment it is fun,
for people that like the intimacy of boardgames it is fun,
I do not recommend it for impatient kids that can't sit still for 15 minutes, because fun will not be had.

Is it worth the money the expansion sets cost?
That is something everyone needs to decide for themselves, in comparison I'd say it's not too steep
(although I'm tight enough to have weighed these words before typing them).
All in all, (and I'm liking it more every time I play a game without crashing),
I give the game a careful 6.7 out of 10.

Please take my playing time into account, which isn't very long, check the reviews of those who have been playing it for longer, or you know, take the plunge!

Greetings fellow travellores and connaisseurs of Trollplaying games (TPG's)

reviewText:
I spent 10 hours playing 2 matches (versus 3x AI, at speed 4).

Cons:
-There are meaningful decisions to be made, but they are dwarfed by RNG.
-It therefore follows that hours of building up can be undone in seconds.
-Once a player makes it to the Crown, it seems there is little that can be done.
-Matches take a very long time if you see them all the way through.
-Clunky magic system. It would be much better if every player was asked to pass, rather than give 5 seconds to cast.
-Bit buggy? Sometimes mechanics are not applied [correctly]?

Pros:
-...I spent 10 hours playing 2 matches. Clearly, despite the cons, this is just fun for me on some bizarre, torturous level!

reviewText:
There's no satisfaction in winning or losing as the entire game (except for the spells aspect) is based 100% on luck. I'd never thought I'd find a game based more on luck than Monopoly, but here it is. If you like to strategize then this game is not for you, your ability to reach the end and win is purely determined by dice rolls and luck of draw cards (all dice rolls are pre-calculated before the game starts).

No strategy will overcome events like being turned into a toad 7 times within 8 turns (yes this did happen) or losing a fight with a 60/50 chance of winning 13 times in a row (yes this happened too).

Talisman is really just a dice simulator with music and ren fair style graphics, and just ended up in my uninstall pile.

reviewText:
Incredibly fun and infuriating at the same time.  Requires more than 1 play through for you to really appreciate the game, and while the game is heavily luck dependant, there is strategy in managing your resources and coming up with plans to try and succeed from almost all points of the game.  You could be 2 turns from being the winner and then fnd yourself turned toad if youve wasted all your resources getting to where you are.  Two good bonuses to the already good game are that

1) The bots are very well made and provide an excellent alternative for when you dont have friends to play with or cant find an open game online
2) With the exception of the specific character DLC, as long as the host of a game owns a content DLC, players without the DLC can still join and play with the content (they still wont be able to use the DLC characters however)

reviewText:
This is a good game, and it seems entirely faithful to the original (although I only played the original once with my uncle long ago, so I could be wrong on that).
$15 dollars might be a bit pricy for what it offers.  I waited for a sale to bring it down to about $5.
The only issue I take with the game is the AI's reticence to go towards the center of the map, even when they've become very powerful and could easily beat the game (you have to reach the center of the map to win, if you didn't know).  Otherwise, the AI is generally fairly competent.
The game is interesting and pretty replayable.  It doesn't offer too much RPing, but it does offer some strategy (even if most of it takes the form of managing various risks).  It makes for a great way to kill some time, and is very easy to pick up and get into.

reviewText: Okay, I just bought the Talisman 4th Edition Boardgame as a B-Day gift for myself.  Started playing it last week w/ my 10-yr old.  We're having F-U-N-!-!  However, he has a curfew, and I have a long work commute, so we play maybe 30 minutes a night and it's slow.  Still fun.  However, I found this Digital Edition, and O My God is it FUN!  Just won my first match ever (boardgame or PC) and it was awesome.  I think what I like most about it is that the Digital Edition really enforces the rules quite a bit on what I would have considered grey areas" of the original rules for the boardgame.  I am very fond of this game and would highly recommend this over the Prologue edition.  Prologue does NOT allow you to play with at least one other AI opponent
date: and that kind of sucks!  You learn a lot more playing with a full-on opponent.  This one tonight (Priest) in particular really had me on the ropes
recommended: the one I played last night (Assasin) not so much.  Any Hearthstone players out there?  Give this a shot - much MORE strategy and the animations are just as fun!  Could not recommend more!"

reviewText:
Buggy as hell.

Have the board game for this, picked up this version in the humble bundle and had a game with two other friends online.

So many bugs.  Turns getting stuck, getting kicked out with odd error messages,  multiple disconnections.  Each time you can get back in, but the AI will have taken a turn or two for you.  Happened to everyone playing.

Basically, imagine playinga  board game where you might be told you have to go outside and come back in before taking a turn at random, and when you do the board might not be the same as when you left it.

The board game is excellent, stick with that and skip this.
voteText: 1 of 2 people (50%) found this review helpful

reviewText:
The interface is counterintutive and possibly buggy. You can cast a spell and then be left wondering why the moves you're trying to make are invalid. There's no feedback. For example, I just spent about an hour playing through a game and then cast a spell that let me to eliminate any face up encounter card. I clicked on literally every single card on the board. Nothing happened. I have no idea what the game wanted from me, but I was left with no way to progress and no way to cancel the action. I just had to quit. All that time was wasted.

The game itself, well, it's Talisman. Classic Ameritrash with absolutely no strategy. For the most part, things just happen.

ETA: Played more to be fair and encountered AI entering infinite loops. I stand by my review.

reviewText: Awesome game board.  Each tile can be an adventure onto itself, huge variety of cards in the draw deck.  Excellent conversion of boardgame to computer.  Handles excellently with context-aware menus.  Unfortunately, it's all in the service of a frankly boring King of the Hill scenario.  Infinite respawn until someone reaches the center square, permadeath afterwards.  50% chance that if there's only one character in the center square, all other characters take damage.  If there's more  than one character in the center square then the damage-to-all-else effect turns off while they battle it out.  Considering how easy it is to gain life...\n\nIf Nomad Games Limited had any other games then I would highly recommend checking them out considering the amount of depth and quality shown here - but they don't seem to have any available.

reviewText:
Talisman: Digital Edition은 1~6인용 보드게임 Talisman 4판을 Nomad Games Limited에서 PC 및 휴대기기용으로 제작한 1~4인용 게임입니다. 일전에 이에 앞서 유료데모로 내놓는 만행을 벌였던 Talisman: Prologue에 대해서 리뷰( http://etude87.tistory.com/97 )한 적이 있는데 그것의 완성판으로 2014년 2월 26일에 출시되었습니다.

PC 이식 및 네트워크 멀티플레이를 지원한다는 장점이 있으나 멍청한 A.I와 기본 구조적 한계 그리고 각종 멀티플레이를 저어하게 만드는 요소들로 인해 Talisman: Digital Edition은 싹수부터 노랗다는 것을 다시 한번 증명했습니다. 타인에게 썩 추천하고 싶지 않습니다만 비교적 저렴한 가격과 휴대용 기기용으로도 많이 나왔으니 친구들과 모여서 보드게임 하고 싶을 때 실물 대신 사용하는 정도로는 쓸모가 있을 것입니다. 더 자세한 내용은 블로그 포스트( http://etude87.tistory.com/179 )를 참고.

ps. 최근 시즌패스 내용물 관련해서 차후 추가될 모든 컨텐츠 제공이란 문구를 수정하고 열번째 캐릭터팩을 시즌패스 적용외 물품으로 내놓으면서 커뮤니티 허브에서도 말이 많아진 상태입니다.

reviewText:
Trying this on the free play weekend. 9 hours, 3 playthroughs against 3 AI opponents.
The good:
- addictive gameplay - would play with friends
- content? (DLC, yeah...)
The bad:
- late game phases can get slow, even on max AI speed
- BUGS. I had to kill the game on 2 different occassions, one of them being a crash to desktop. On another, a card effect (reduces movement to 1) got stuck on me despite the AI having and then discarding the actual card. Ended up quitting that game too. The game also loses fullscreen mode on each Alt-Tab.

As is, I might still grab the main game on sale. No DLC though - I wouldn't want to support game devs who prioritise DLCs over fixing major bugs.

reviewText:
I want to enjoy this game, I really do, but there are 3 problems:

1.  This game is unbalanced, with some characters being clearly better than other characters.
2.  The interface is terrible.  Spells are incredibly difficult to cast correctly with no ability to decide whether you cast the spell or not based on the presumed result.  Once you click the button, a cavalcade of unintended consequences occur just because you cast it in the wrong phase.
3.  You have very little control over the course of the game.  It is a long game of fantasy Monopoly.  You roll die that determine your fate entirely.

It clearly was created at a time where quantity in a game was more important than quality or balance.

reviewText: I am a board game enthusiast.  I can say with high level of certainty this is the WORST balanced board game I have ever played.  The game design is terrible and mind boggling.  I honestly wonder if they had any playtesting before release.\n\nIn addition to the terrible balance issues, the online versions UI is abysmal.  Trying to full screen either gives me a black screen half the time or freezes up.  Casting spells that require any type of timing is almost impossible.  There is no undue button and many commands do not have confirm request.  Do not play this game if you value your time in any way.

reviewText: Well I wasn't expecting something awesome, but after half hour my interest changed into bitterness. A lots of classes is what I really liked about this game. Besides of the evil dice you get a lot of bugs like getting stuck after spell failure because you press some key on the keyboard and there is nothing you can do except for quiting the game. Your raft won't work, your items and so on ... and I experienced this in about 2 hours ... so you can make a picture.

reviewText:
One of the best board games of a long past era, Talisman evokes the core of 1980s RNG heavy dice rolling board games. For those of us who lived in that time, before Germany came along and showed the world how great board games can be, this is a well realized throwback nostalgia title.

That's not to say Talisman is a great board game. It's really not. It's exceptionally RNG heavy and can be frustrating at times. But, it's also pretty fun. Particularly when playing with a group of friends over Skype, Mumble, etc. The game itself is very easy to learn. Roll a die. Move. Do what's on the board. Try to improve your character enough to get to the center, defeat the challenge, and win the game.

The software implementation of Talisman by Nomad is pretty good. The animations and sounds are good, the graphics are pretty, and it plays the way you would expect. We've only run into a few bugs, one game-breaking, over a bunch of sessions. One of the really nice things Nomad did was allow the host's version of Talisman to be played. I have the full season pack, and a bunch of my friends have the core game only. I host, and we can play with all of the expansions.

There are 3 expansions out so far. The best one at the moment is The Dungeon, which adds a large board segment to one of the corners. I'm very much looking forward to when all of the expansions are out and you can play a big mega game.

Game time can run a bit long. While this is faster than the tabletop version, budget about one hour per player per game.

I recommend, but this definitely isn't for everyone. I sunk about 100 hours into Talisman Prologue (which was their single-player Beta" version of this and about a dozen hours so far for the full release. This is a fun one to pull out once in a while with friends

reviewText: I used to play this game often with my old roomates twenty years ago. This is an amazing adaptation. The graphics are awesome and faithfully reproduce the board. It would really be nice if other board games could make the digital transition like this one. My only real complaint is that the AI seemed like it was cheating since it would regularily get the rolls it needed to win some unlikely battles or land on a coveted card. I found myself using an exploit to get around the questionable rolls but recently it was updated and the exploit no longer works. The new update seems to generate a dice table the same way many other digital dice games do. I got the season pass for this one also and have been loving all the DLC. The Dungeon is pretty cool. If you liked the original board game then this one is a must. Its easy to loose many hours here.

reviewText:
For those who can't get to an actual table often (or at all) this is a great alternative to play Talisman.  Don't know what it is?  Think Fantasy Monopoly and you sort of have the idea, only instead of buying properties and gathering cash and boning your friends, you're fighting monsters, gathering treasure, gambling money, and... well, boning your friends.  It's an all-time classic board game.

Only downside is they charge about the same amount for the DLC as they do for the real game's expansions, so if you actually can get a good regular gaming group together, getting the actual game is probably a much better course of action for you.

Note: as of this writing, the DLC list has shrunk down to three, so the above comment may no longer be valid, but during the Early Access, you could see listed all the expansions for the physical game at the same price.  This may turn up later.

EDIT: Don't know why my play counter is 0.  I've definitely played this a helluvalot more than that.

reviewText: Talisman: Digital Edition is the game that took me for supprise, I have played Board game in a hobby shop a couple of years back but decided agenst buying due to the long, tedius gameplay.... Talisman the board game is a whole day adventure!... However the Digital Edition takes all the tedium out of talisman and gives it a shiny new set of paint!... It is a game that plays EXACTLY like the board game, sped up. you can play at your own pace, pause-able, save-able and ability to play on line! i got this for 5 bucks during 2014 Steam sale and it is the most played game i got the entire sale, i played one game than baught all the expantions.... if you love board-games or fantasy anything Get it...get it now....

reviewText:
Incredibly fun and infuriating at the same time.  Requires more than 1 play through for you to really appreciate the game, and while the game is heavily luck dependant, there is strategy in managing your resources and coming up with plans to try and succeed from almost all points of the game.  You could be 2 turns from being the winner and then fnd yourself turned toad if youve wasted all your resources getting to where you are.  Two good bonuses to the already good game are that

1) The bots are very well made and provide an excellent alternative for when you dont have friends to play with or cant find an open game online
2) With the exception of the specific character DLC, as long as the host of a game owns a content DLC, players without the DLC can still join and play with the content (they still wont be able to use the DLC characters however)

reviewText:
There's no satisfaction in winning or losing as the entire game (except for the spells aspect) is based 100% on luck. I'd never thought I'd find a game based more on luck than Monopoly, but here it is. If you like to strategize then this game is not for you, your ability to reach the end and win is purely determined by dice rolls and luck of draw cards (all dice rolls are pre-calculated before the game starts).

No strategy will overcome events like being turned into a toad 7 times within 8 turns (yes this did happen) or losing a fight with a 60/50 chance of winning 13 times in a row (yes this happened too).

Talisman is really just a dice simulator with music and ren fair style graphics, and just ended up in my uninstall pile.

reviewText:

It's a great game, there can be some mind blowing difficulties every now and then that could use some fixing, but overall I'm enjoying this game. Great expansions as well.

Against AI it's okay, but as usual, playing games with friends is more enjoyable than playing alone against AI's.

reviewText: This is a nice digital rendition of the original boardgame. It is however somewhat limited in how you play cards, and there should really be an option when you cue a card to be played where you get a question if you want to play it or not when a situation triggers where the card can be played. Currently you have to time certain cards very precisely and you'll end up targeting yourself with bad spells and throw away other cards simply because the game is programmed so that if you cue a card you mindlessly play it on whatever is a legal target. Ruins a lot of the fun unfortunately. If they patch this the game will be close to perfect in it's resemblance of the original boardgame.

reviewText:
Lots of bugs and the game takes way too long to go anywhere.
If, like me, you're somewhat of a noob to role-playing games of this nature, it can be completely soul-crushing to be the loser in a game that took 2 hours to complete. That being said, I only played a few matches against the AI, and a single match against a friend and 2 AI. Maybe if you have 3 friends to play with while Skyping or such it could be fun, however there's still the matter of the bugs that even a newbie player like me was noticing (spells not working/casting/targetting etc) , bugs I've seen others here comment about also.

Got this game for free on Steam this weekend, and I'm glad I did; It was just enough time for me to realise I never want to play it again, lol

reviewText: The game premise is pretty good and I think I would enjoy the actual board game, but as it stands the digital version of the game is somewhat poorly made. I've had numerous glitches occur, and some aspects of the interface are rather annoying. My biggest complaint so far is having played a game as a Ninja the victory condition made it impossible to win. I was required to obtain 2 followers and then discard them in order to complete a Warlock Quest. Ninjas can not have followers. Therefore  I couldn't win. I got a cursed item that made me lose all of my quests, which I used to get rid of that quest and go take a different Warlock quest, to which the game made me take the same quest again, with no roll or anything even though the spot said to roll for it. I did have some irratations with the interface, but those could be avoided once a player becomes familiar with the game. The games been out long enough that really big glitches like this should probably have been patched out. Theres also very squirly things with the NPC players where they will often drag on their turns for a while picking up every single item on a square, and then put every item back down because they lack inventory space, even though they won't take any of the actual items. I could go on, but I got the game for a steal so I can't complain too much. Thinking im going to go buy the board game now though. I rather like the actual game.

You thought Dark Souls was a harsh game? Let me educate you son. Dark Souls ain't got ♥♥♥♥ on Talisman.

this game tortured each and every one of us to the point of break only to continue then to kill us mercilessly.
nothing can be harsher them this game's RNG. now i'm ready for real life. now i'm ready to be an adult.

reviewText: If you enjoy the board game, chances are you'll enjoy this. It's essentially just the board game in video game form, which I personally view as a positive. Now, if you can't get a group of friends together to play, you have the option to play against AI or other players online.  Much like the board game, expansions are purchased separately, so keep that in mind.  But the game does come with options for some popular house rules.  My only complaints are that the interface is a little hard to navigate at first and the game only supports up to 4 players instead of 6, but they aren't huge problems that really hamper the game.  In short, I'd recommend to any Talisman fans out there!

reviewText: Brilliant digitial port of this classical adventure boardgame!  If you liked playing the original boardgame you cannot go wrong buying this. reviewText:
Talisman is a game of adventure, excitement, and challenge; a game where you the player are the ones who build the cross the AI nails you to. Dying from a gut seeping wound might be more enjoyable. If you reach the crown before the AI, you better expect to choke hard and roll absolutely abysmal. If you think the AI is doing something stupid? It's because the AI has decided to give you this illusion before three turns later it's suddenly twice as strong wielding magic faster than a video game player can blame a computer for his failings. This game is not your friend. This game hates you. This game lives off of your suffering. Any achievement is to lull you into a false sense of security. All hail your new dark gods, the AI.

10/10 Would forsake my first born child to actually roll what I need when I need it.

P.S. SHODAN is more merciful than this game.
voteText: 1 of 2 people (50%) found this review helpful

reviewText:
This game is a lot of fun. It is definitely best played with a group of friends which you can converse with. To be entirely honest, it is not that great if you play against the AI. The AI has this ability to screw themselves in ways that are entirely possible to avoid with a little bit of thought. For instance, the AI will use an axe to get across the river only to cross back to the outer area the next turn.

I would highly recommend this to people which enjoy tabletop games which contain both an element of strategy and an element of luck. There is a lot in this game which requires luck, but once you have played a few games, you can get a feel of what the better spaces and strategies are. Playing with random characters also forces you to get used to new ways of playing the game, making each game much different from the last.

Keep in mind, a single string of bad luck can pretty much end your run in the game or force you to play catch up for the remainder of the game if everyone else is doing well.

reviewText:
This game is the pure representation of board roleplaying.

For some people, gameplay may seem too slow. Well, if you are not aiming to watch your opponent's moves, this is not your game. The depth during the match grows linearly with time, and luck is as well an important factor that usually decides.

Overall it is hard to survive against encounters themselves, and there is some fun behind it, still needed to be polished.

There are many bugs and translation errors, but since they are aiming to release more content, let's hope for the fixes.

reviewText:
Incredibly fun and infuriating at the same time.  Requires more than 1 play through for you to really appreciate the game, and while the game is heavily luck dependant, there is strategy in managing your resources and coming up with plans to try and succeed from almost all points of the game.  You could be 2 turns from being the winner and then fnd yourself turned toad if youve wasted all your resources getting to where you are.  Two good bonuses to the already good game are that

1) The bots are very well made and provide an excellent alternative for when you dont have friends to play with or cant find an open game online
2) With the exception of the specific character DLC, as long as the host of a game owns a content DLC, players without the DLC can still join and play with the content (they still wont be able to use the DLC characters however)

reviewText:
Hey everyone and this is my review about the game!

This is a Card Board game.


Interface/Menu/Settings
You are able to change the Sound volume by 10 everytime.
You are able to change the Music Volume by 10 everytime.
There are some Different languages available.
You can play fullscreen, You have to press that Expand button in the options"
You can play Local or against he AI.
There is online mode. (with a small group of people playing.) (You can make private or online lobbies and no port forward required).
Able to make different save and you can rename this.

About the game.

There are different characters. Each character has their own powers. You are able to choose Random too. There is a tutorial ingame. The object of the game is that you have to reach the middle of the board and kick other players out of this. Each character has their own set of Health/fighting power/Gold/Fate/craft and abilities. Some even could have an alignment to be Neutral/Evil and good. You have to fight enemies and get followers.
There are cards to make things better or worse for you. You have to make your character powerful in order to defeat the bridge boss (unless you have found another way to enter inside the middle area).  Winning from an enemy character gives you the option to steal 1 item
date: take gold or let them lose one life point.\n\nMANY CHARACTERS
recommended:
Killing enemies gives you their card and may be used to make yourself powerful if having enough of these cards.
You are able to speed up turns from the AI in the ADVANCED OPTIONS menu.
Game is sort of addictive.
Music soundtrack is good.
Calming game.
There is a pause button.

Other things.
This game gives me the "jumanji" Feelings from the movie.
The game at the bottom will glow yellow whenever it is your turn.
Random AI like to choose the same characters in a game.
Game feel sometimes rigged and could give you a nice disadvantage.

-------------------

I Give this game a 7/10"

reviewText:
I've never played Talisman before and would probably never get a chance in my country, so digital versions do come in handy. I've played a few matches and although game is complex (great), rich and detailed (excellent) and full of amazing details and additional content (nice, nice, supernice), I've always had a feeling I am being cheated out of dice rolls. Even compared to Chainsaw Warrior, card game that really snuffs out the players 9 out of 10 times, this game always felt way too artificial under the colorful hood.

Well now...

I've uninstalled the game and reinstalled it today when I saw there's a Humble Bundle package with some additional content available for a low price. I was just about to buy and indulge in playing muted Talisman and listening to audiobook again when a buddy of mine made me read a shocking post by a developer himself.

That post is available at Steam's community hub for Talisman: Digital Edition and it explains in detail the horrid decision of game devs that I really don't understand at all.

The most important part is this one and no, it's not taken out of context:

At the start of a new game
date: a huge list of random numbers between 1 and 6 is generated. That list of numbers is used for the whole game
recommended: in the order that they are determined at this point."\n\nI understand it this way - in the game based on factor of random dice rolls
hoursPlayed: you get a predetermined row of numbers which influence your moves. There are no true random dice rolls
voteText: no luck. Only a rigging generator.\n\nThis decision truly crushes my enthusiasm to play this game any longer and to buy any new content. I am sorry
helpfulPercent: but I don't see any point of dice rolling when my game is (almost completely) predetermined. When I buy a game that relies on dice rolls
votesHelpful: I want random dice rolls. There's no excuse for this sad state of affairs and although I never do this
votesTotal: I urge you all to vote this review up so people prove to the devs changes have to be made to make a great game - great."
