reviewText: I used to play the tabletop version of this many moons ago when I was a wee lad. I don't know if you can still buy them, but back then you could get, like, a dozen expansions that came with additional game boards like a dungeon and one that allowed you to travel through space. My brother and I liked playing the expansions more than the vanilla game because every expansion added these wicked overpowered new characters and objects and instead of the usual gameplay strat of just travel around the outer region for a half an hour to level up before going towards the middle" it became "bum rush the space lanes to get the laser rifle and the anti-grav belt and spend the next fifteen minutes griefing the other players until they get mad and give up".\n\nDad says: If you like this kind of nerd ♥♥♥♥
date: it's a pretty good buy at $5
recommended: but bear in mind that the vanilla game will get old after a couple of hours once you're familliar with all the cards and/or you don't have actual people to play with on mumble. You'll be wanting to get some of the expansions if you enjoy it and those will cost like $5 each
hoursPlayed: but they should mix up the game enough that you'll find lots of added enjoyment. I really can't recommend paying full price for everything unless you're one of those board game spergs."

reviewText: A  fun and entertaining game, however the AI is complete and utter, bull. I can not stress this idea enough. I spent half an hour trying to kill the only remaining Swashbuckler in a 1 vs. 5 AI game. He would not simply die. What i mean by this, is that he would honestly get down to 1 life point remaining and then miraculously roll the die into the perfect number to land on a square in which he could heal. It did not also help that he had a card that gave him a minimum of 1 gold at all times. The game finally ended when the AI moved him into the most inner ring where he had no methods of self healing.\n\nOverall it's a great game and lives up to the experiences i've had through the actual irl gameboard. However this game requires a lot of patience. I don't reccommend this game if you don't like waiting forever to end the game. (If the turns are slow, you can fix that in the advaced settings.)

reviewText:
There are alot of things done good in this game: They didn't change the rules or the cards, the graphics is good, the AI's play reasonably good. This is a good didgital rendering of a fantastic board-game.
The problem is the pace.

In Real-life board game your opponents are human. You have fun sitting around the table passing time and gaming. But when playing against AIs waiting isn't fun. It's annoying and tiresome.
And the AI in this game thinks SLOWLY. VERY VERY SLOWLY. Even on maximum speed.
And the graphics. Oh the graphics. It's good. Really. But SLOW. SO SO SLOW. The well intended animation of everything from rolling a die to the turn shifting to the next player makes the turns unbearably long. So long infact I got up made popcorn, and came back to find it's still isn't my turn.
So slow I find myself incapable of playing the game without doing atleast one more thing.

This game would have been a 9/10 if you had a No animation" option. Without it the pace of the game is so slow I'm compeled to give it a 3/10 - Nice try."

reviewText:
I cannot, in good conscience, recommend this game. Whilst I have many fond memories of Talisman from my childhood, this is a terrible implementation of a game that has long past exceeded its best-by date.

Talisman itself is sadly lacking in the current era of boardgames, with little to no strategy or choice left to the player. It is dictated far more by the random roll of the die, than any particular desire of the player. Even Monopoly provides more strategy, and choice of action. This is a faithful implementation of the original, for what little that is worth.

The main issue is the interface, which is an abomination. Trying to play with friends rapidly becomes an excercise in extreme frustration, wherein you battle the shoddy controls - instead of battling your friends. Laggy, unresponsive and unintuitive are the nicest words I have to say about it. I wish I could refund it, and I feel terrible for gifting it to several of my friends who now all have a much poorer opinion of me.

If you have any fondness for Talisman, any decent memories of the game - leave them as that, memories. Playing this game will leave only a bitter taste in your mouth of ashes and defeat. Nomad Games has my money - please dont give them yours.

reviewText:
You'll have already read what the game is: a faithful recreation of a board-game classic with high fidelity to the original, a somewhat sketchy interface, a few bugs, and the same glacial pacing as if you were playing around a table, minus the board setup.

AI is one of the keys to transition between in-person and computer-based play. The programmers haven't solved that problem well at all. Computer opponents don't have much strategy besides accumulating stats and items. They perform like mediocre bots in the single-player training missions of an online FPS. A human player would wipe the table with them every time, except the AI appears to get a boost via favorable die rolls and card draws, likely to disguise its lack of real strategy. The first few games this doesn't matter much, but after dozens of games it sucks the enjoyment out of it.

If you have 3 friends willing to play the game with you, I'd buy this game in a heartbeat. If you're going to fill in with computer players--and especially if you just want to play single-player--this is probably a pass.

For that reason--plus constant problems connecting with servers resulting in interrupted games--I have to give this game a no vote even though I generally like it. It's not a horrible purchase, just know what you're getting into.

reviewText:
I picked this game up for $5.  At that price, you really can't go that wrong.  That being said, this game really walks the line between whether or not to give it a positive or a negative review overall.

The design flaws of the Talisman game really manifest itself when you play with a rigid, impassionate interpreter of the game.   This doesn't seem like a bad thing, but Talisman has evolved over the years with very little consistency: there's a huge variety of nuances in the language used.  Phrases such as ...at any time..." implies a different expectation than what is actually practiced in the game.

The honest truth is

This is not just my experience - all of my friends experience the same thing, and a quick search online shows that many people are fed up with these same problems. reviewText:
There is a lot to be said about the charm of nostelgia... but not enough to deflect the idea that time can be cruel and that some things, like Talisman, do not age well.

This game is quite a nice digital version of a boardgame from long ago, but as such it does not have the benefits granted from all the game development that would come after it.
That is not meant to be a cruel jab, if anything is is an apology for why I can't find much positive to say.

All you really need to know is that this game is an excercise in being given a very small set (usually 2) of options each turn based on the roll of a die. those options are then resolved throught the roll of another die... and then that loop is repeated for about an hour or more with plenty of long pauses taken at random intervals.
Your input into this game is so small, and the luck so great that it is hard to truely feel that this game needs you to be present, or that any sucess or failure is yours to claim.

The translation from cardboard to digital is well done and smooth in most places, but does have a few flaws, (there is no option to hide all of the A.I.'s desicion making if you are playing with bots, and it can only be sped up so much in the options... meaning that your already drawn out experiance is now stretched further and thinner.)

It can be applauded for being such a faithful replication of a board game, but as to wether that excersice is, itself, worthwhile, my feelings lead towards: No.

If you are an old board gamer who maybe missed out on this little bit of gaming history and wanted to experiance it, this is a good way to do so, but if you are anyone else, there are better digital board games, much better non-digital board games, and infinitely better digital adventure simulators.

Try any of them before this.

reviewText:
Unless you're a huge fan of the original board game you might want to give this a pass.

On the surface it's fine. There's a board. There are cards, characters and a die. Great.

Unfortunately once you actually start to play you realize pretty quickly that you're dealing with a tablet port that's had oodles of time put into it on the dlc-front, but not so much on  the optimizing-for-pc front. There's the base game, then several expansions, then I don't even know how many characters for a buck or three apiece, and there ain't a thing wrong with any of that assuming the game plays well and stable on the average pc.

That's where things begin to break down. There's a very long-standing and unresolved bug affecting a lot of people wherein if you afk from the game for anything more than about 60 seconds or so you'll return to a frozen screen, which you can only fix" by force-closing the game in Task Manager and restarting. reviewText:
Do not buy unless it is on sale for $1.
Talisman is one of the best board games that have ever come out. However, I am talking about the original board game, not the digital edition. I am not going to describe the single player feature as it is very poor and AI does not demand any thinking from the player, making the single player game easy, boring and discouraging. Therefore, I will concetrate on the multiplayer feature since it is the only feature worth looking at.

The rules are very simple: roll a dice, move that many spaces, draw a card or cards, read them and d what the instruction tells you to do. Simple isn't it? Well, for developers it is not simple. The game is full of bugs and developers insist on working on new addons instead of correcting existing bugs. In other words - the game is not finished and really rushed and I need to point out it was released a long time ago. Too long for such issues to happen.

The game can freeze or crash just after loading it. I experienced game freeze on the main menu several times - solution, do not leave the game on the title screen or it will stop responding. You will be forced to start the game again and/or start Steam again, and/or reboot your system.
The game was not properly tested before release and it is more than obvious.
A lot of cards do not work as they are supposed to. Many card effects lead to a dead end as you will not be able to do anything (I see that problem with many spells while casted on other players). Example: after casting for example, Misfortune spell on the opponent, the game stopped responding and did not give any player any opportunity to make their moves, the game stops, the timeout counter freezes and you or any other player is forced to leave the game in order to make it move on.
Connection issues occur every game. Some players are kicked out of the server for no reason. Sometimes you cannot go back to the game you were playing.
After joining the server and starting or looking for a game, your game can stop responding, forcing you to reboot your game and ocassionally your Steam and/or your system.
Who put Quit button in the Settings? Standing ovation for the analysts/architects/developers and anyone responsible for this sensible chuckle design. I laughed, my friends laughed. Good comedy.
There is no way to speed up the game play. It goes very long and I played some games for such a long time that I do not recall any actual board games to last that long (and I played with 7 people at a time!). You have to wait for every action even if no action is available at the moment. For example: even though you have only one choice, the system does not automatically go with the only choice but waits for you to select it. Bad idea.
There is a number cards that do not work properly or do not work at all and when it comes tot he interaction betwen some cards, majority of such situations lead to a glitch, mostly forcing you to rejoin the game or restarting it.
Each new addon comes with a new set of bugs. Beware.
Random Number Generator is really poor and developers should think before they do something rigged as this. There is a chance that you will throw 1" for about 5-10 times in a row which is impossible if you were really rolling dice. This NEEDS to be fixed. I remember rolling the same set of numbers several times in a row. Bad development. There is no explanation for such bad execution of dice roll simulation.
You can be kicked out of the game without any chance (yes!) for coming back. The game tends to bug out and nothing can be done to go back to it. Progress is lost. The most disappointing.
Inviting your Steam friends is very buggy. I have never successfully invited anyone without a crash
date:
so I do not use that feature.


TL;DR - If you want to play the great game which is Talisman - go and buy the original board game
recommended: you will never have to reboot anything

reviewText:
Talisman is the classic adventure board game of powerful magic and ferocious creatures. Play as one of many classic fantasy archetypes such as an elf, wizard, monk, thief (and many more!) as you gain experience, powerful items/weapons, followers, spells and so on. Adventure around the board until you're ready to tackle the dreaded inner region, reach the Crown of Command, and claim victory!

If you like gameplay that is all about playing the odds, you'll probably enjoy yourself in Talisman. At first glance it seems like a simple roll-and-move game where the player has little control over what happens to them during any given turn, but it's actually very involved as winning requires understanding how to create good odds for yourself. It's also a game where you need to understand that bad things WILL happen and there's nothing you could've done about it; or even if you lost a fight you shoulda won - it's ok because 80% odds in your favor means you'll still lose 20% of the time.

Talisman is a very interesting mix of a laid back casual game (because of how simple any given turn is) and also a very cutthroat game. Players will clash in many PvP battles over the course of a game and powerful items will switch hands as players take them from each other through force or other means. You'll need to always take into account the other players, knowing which ones you should target and which ones will target you.

So if you like fantasy adventure and gameplay that's all about navigating the wims of random luck, I highly recommend Talisman. It's a light game that manages to capture that feeling of going on an epic quest and overcoming great challenges. There's a reason this game is still around despite many bigger and more involved adventure board games being released since the 80s, so play this digital adaptation and find out what makes Talisman so special.

reviewText: A little bit too complex for its own good.   A game took me a good two hours with myself and three AI's, and you couldn't speed the AI turns up enough for my liking. I would like to try the board game though.\n\nI played two more games to completion with 2 AI's, and the game is just way too random.  The frog mechanic can move a character from first to last place instantly, and sometimes there's nothing you can do to prevent it.  Getting the rolls you need to win is incredibly difficult, and once someone gets to the Crown of Power they almost always win.

reviewText:
Talisman is a very poor board game to begin with. Main game mechanic is frustrating the player. A dice game that goes on for 3-8 hours.
The Digital edition is a bad port of the board game. It forces you to watch hundreds of die-roll animations every game. It's bug-ridden and you can not expect anything to work at any time - it will just not function, at random critical moments. Interaction with the game is often non-intuitive and cluncky. You can forget multiplayer as it crashes at random roughly 9 of 10 games.
Talisman Digital Edition runs a DLC greed-scheme, where they offer you the game piecemeal for an insane price.
This is as bad as it gets.

reviewText:
2 Words: DLC marketplace. Its one thing when you have dlc in your game, its another when the minute I try to create a game I'm slammed in the face for not having 90% of the content available. This is most evident in the player selection where it shows you the 6 heroes you own and the 50+ that you do not in a hodgepodge of little icons with no labels.

Look, I can understand having DLC as a part of the game, but DLC constitutes almost 4 times what the base game has to offer. And if you really want to enjoy this game, its basically mandatory.

Avoid this marketing strategy and avoid this company. A 14.99 game should not feel like an incomplete experience and have dlc content that is pushed this heavily on its players. Expansions are fair, but DLC should not be required to enjoy the game nor be pushed as heavily.

reviewText: This is a faithful re-creation of Talisman the boardgame, and that's its problem.  Talisman is a dreadfully prolonged lesson on the fate of die rolls, which will see you endlessly sliding back and forth until you luck out and roll whatever number you needed, which will push you toward the end game, until, of course, a single unlucky die roll sends you spinning back to square one and adds 90 more minutes onto the play time of this terrible, outdated game.  I suppose if you like the original treadmill of futility that is Talisman, you'll like this game, too.

reviewText: Plays really slow. Compared to Talisman: Prologue, I would say just buy whichever is on sale. Both have slow interfaces and annoying control methods. The actual board game is legendarily slow to play and these two games take the physical slowness out of the equation, but insert slowness and clunky controls where you feel like virtuality would lend itself to smoothness.\nSometimes you need to click the board to do a thing and the game will interpret your click as something else, and you'll mess up your turn. Sometimes the game's controls will screw you. All I can recommend is to be as careful as you can.\nIf you're a big fan of Talisman but you don't have friends who want to play the game on Steam with you, just buy the real board game. And if your friends want to play the Steam version with you, know that it will be annoying.

reviewText:
First off, unless I'm mistaken, this is my first Steam review. I hate that it's negative, but I am way too ticked off at this game NOT to give it a negative review. Second, this game makes me wish I had bought it AFTER the Stean refund policy change. I would refund this pile in a heartbeat. Now let me get into the things I hated about the game. Also, for the most part, you are not going to read anything here that are not in the other reviews. If you like the board game, you might like this if you don't crash. If not my gripes are similair to others

So, I bought this game a few months ago, but never got around to playing it. I left Neverwinter Nights, and get a pop-up saying if I buy a character for Talisman the profits with go to charity. Great! I love to help charity. And it is a shaman. Shamans and Druids are some of my favorite characters. So load up the game, and search the main page for a tutorial. There's none, which is troubling, but I figure, 'hey, it's probably a tutorial as you play kind of game'. Which it is. Problem is you ghave to choose your character with stats that you have NO CLUE what they do. So I do what I always do in a fantasy game where I'm not sure about the mechanics. I pick the Warrior, because it is almost aways the easiest class. I also make sure there is only one  opponent, because i wanted the make the game as easy as possiblee.

Then I get into the game. My first turn I roll, get a 6 move to the temple. My whole strategy tois to get the two weapons that the fighter can have, then play from there. I roll again, then have to fight an ape. I lose. No prob. It's the beginning of the game, and I can't expect to win every dice roll. Now I don't remember all my opponents turns, (partly because he was taking turns when I was reading text) but basically he didn't have ONE bad thing happen on any of his turns. So, I take my thirds turn and fight a creature with craft, and lose again. Next turn, roll again, got a dragon, lost again. Now mind you, you don't get a choice on whether to fight or not. Some classes give some choice in some situations, but mostly, roll and get blssed or f-d. So, I'm down 3 lives, and have some event where I lose ANOTHER LIFE! My opponent. Again, my opponent has lost no life, and hasn't even had to fight. I am a WARRIOR and I have won no fights. I just want a weapon. So I spend my one gold to get back 1 hp because I am at one HP. THEN I get the second gold that would have allowed me to get a weapon.  Then I roll a demon which I would have to roll a 6 to tie. So back to 1 hp. At this point I say F this game. So I want to see what happens when you die, so I attack the creature with craft (magic) because he should have an advantage. And THEN I win. *Faceplam*

Anyway I was done within 5 minutes of that. My opponent was already in the second ring. This game is JUST RANDOM LUCK. I own 600 on Steam, (though I've prob only played a little over 500 of them) and this will likely wind up on the bottom 50 of them.

reviewText:
My first gameplay...
Picked the Gambler.
Rolled low, went to Tavern. Got drunk, lost a turn.
My next turn.. Rolled low, drew a Dragon with 7 strength that rolled a 6. Lost a life.
My next turn.. Rolled low, drew a Craft 5 creature that rolled high. Lost a life.
My next turn.. Rolled low, drew a Pig with 1 strength.
OMG.. I'm going to beat it. Pig rolled a 5. Beat me by one point. Lost a life.
Lost the game.

Beat by bacon. 10/10 Would lose to bacon again.

---------------------
UPDATE: The game can be fun.. but after finding out that all dice are predetermined at the beginning of the game I will not be recommending this and giving it a thumbs DOWN now. This is a ♥♥♥♥ poor mechanic and development choice for any developer. Why give people the illusion they are rolling a dice for random rolls if they are not truly random when thrown? Those times I'm feeling lucky and end up with those craptastic one's make me feel cheated since I now know they were picked when I started the game. Coding in a SIMPLE RNG routine for each roll is NOT that hard and actually would use less resources than storing up a predetermined roll chart. I know this because I AM a developer. You wanted to prevent people from reloading a game and possibly rolling a better RANDOM roll? **WRONG** The same principle can be used by that same person because they know what the next roll is going to be and they just reload and choose a different course or action. You haven't foiled their attempt to get ahead.
voteText: 2 of 5 people (40%) found this review helpful

reviewText:
Love it. I first played this board game when it came out in the 80's and loved it. I have played it several times since with various expansions and seeing it come to life digitally brought back so many memories.
It is practically identical to the original board game, and does have a few annoying bugs (mostly around spells not quite activating the way they should) but outside of that this is a really well done port of the original.

It is just as unbalanced as the original board game but the runestones go a small way to helping that out, bringing the weaker characters into the mix nicely.

Recommended and looking forward to all the future expansions. Bring on the dungeon!
voteText: 2 of 5 people (40%) found this review helpful

reviewText:
What a pointless game. I've won this game nearly every time I played and I never left with a feeling of satisfaction. The interface of this game is atrocious. You can never make moves efficiently and half the time it is not clear how to use the cards you possess. And pray to the gods that you or your opponents never lose connection temporarily. The worst case scenario- the games takes a dump and everything goes to hell; the best case scenario- the atrocious AI takes over and immediate proceeds to ram as many items as it can into its own eyeballs in an attempt to impress the other players with its edgy suicide performance art.

Really this is a terrible video game implementation of a terrible board game. I've yet to play a game that lasted less than 90min and most have lasted at least 3hrs. It takes no skill to win and the game frequently misinterprets spells or just plain bugs out and hamstrings the front-runner. All games tend toward every player colluding to ensure a swift end to the experience. How can anyone love such an RNG heavy, tedious piece of garbage. Even if you want a long-form RPG-style board game experience (and why would you) there are so  many better ones.

Buy this game if you are a masochist. Buy this game for your friends if you are human trash.

reviewText:
This is not a computer game. It's a board game on a computer, which is perfectly legitimate.

But how does it stack up as a board game? Even there its basic design fails.

Don't get me wrong. There are some great things about this board game, especially the replayability and variety of interesting scenarios (for a board game), if you're willing to fork over money for a lot of DLC. However, where the game fundamentally fails in two areas:

1) You have very little ability to control where your character goes and what it does, which means you can spend long portions of the game just wondering around, rolling dice and seeing what happens (or doesn't happen, as the case may be). This makes the game very luck based, but worse than that, it becomes pretty tedious, especially when the board becomes filled with cards that effectively don't do anything.

2) It's really hard to end the game; partially because the game requires you luck out on a series of dice rolls just to get to the point where the game starts to end; partially because the game doesn't really penalize you at all for trying to power up indefinitely before heading to the end game; and partially because the first character to get to the end of the game gets the dubious honor of being forced to sit there doing nothing but rolling one die to see if maybe they'll do 1 point of damage to the other characters.

With some of the above problems fixed, Talisman could become a fun board game/computer game, but as it is, you spend most of your time waiting for your turn in the hope that you'll get to do something interesting.

reviewText:
The game seems really fun to play and I would love to try the board game some time.

HOWEVER the execution of putting it into software was just an epic fail. Bugs all over the place,

The tutorial to teach a new player lags behind the actual game play (a few times the tutorial messages would pop up and i ended up thinking wow
date:
that would have really helped x turns ago!")

DLC WARNING

This game offers you tons of add-ons to customize the game IF you buy the DLC's! It might be worth it if they were only a dollar or so but 6 dollars per DLC!?!?

And all you get is a few more chars and some cards for a game that is already so buggy its almost unplayable?!?!

just another example of a greedy company that employs a broken DLC system!!! (looking at you EA

reviewText: This is a faithful re-creation of Talisman the boardgame, and that's its problem.  Talisman is a dreadfully prolonged lesson on the fate of die rolls, which will see you endlessly sliding back and forth until you luck out and roll whatever number you needed, which will push you toward the end game, until, of course, a single unlucky die roll sends you spinning back to square one and adds 90 more minutes onto the play time of this terrible, outdated game.  I suppose if you like the original treadmill of futility that is Talisman, you'll like this game, too.

reviewText: Plays really slow. Compared to Talisman: Prologue, I would say just buy whichever is on sale. Both have slow interfaces and annoying control methods. The actual board game is legendarily slow to play and these two games take the physical slowness out of the equation, but insert slowness and clunky controls where you feel like virtuality would lend itself to smoothness.\nSometimes you need to click the board to do a thing and the game will interpret your click as something else, and you'll mess up your turn. Sometimes the game's controls will screw you. All I can recommend is to be as careful as you can.\nIf you're a big fan of Talisman but you don't have friends who want to play the game on Steam with you, just buy the real board game. And if your friends want to play the Steam version with you, know that it will be annoying.

reviewText:
Buy the board game, and walk away quickly from this digital debauchery.

Each of the cards at least seems to work exactly like the board game, though the interface leaves a ton to be desired. Game may crash after finishing a round, stays in windowed mode at all times, ignores most key presses, no help dialogue, and on and on.

The game likes to automate SOME the things that are player choices (like using the Orb of Knowledge) and other times make you click Continue way too many times. The worst part about it is  the inconsistency. There are actually times where your turn is finished for you, even if the timer doesn't run out. Another issue there: there's a mandatory timer! Shortest timer is 30 seconds, longest is 2 min.

Overall, this version taught me some things that were a little confusing in the tabletop version, but via teeth-pulling. If you're a hardcore fan, buyer beware.
voteText: 1 of 3 people (33%) found this review helpful

reviewText: I love board games, and I like a lot of digital versions of board games. This is NOT a good one. If you loooove Talisman and know the rules and cards very well, you may like it. If not...the game is very slow (even at highest speed), clunky, and boring. I only played a couple hours and it literally consisted of clicking dice roll, and then moving that many spaces. This is just not a game that works well without friends present.\n\nAdditionally  the layout of the game is just plain confusing. There were so many times I was trying to click on cards to read them, then accidentally moved there, or did something else. The interface is not intuitive at all.

reviewText: What a worthless, drooling mess of a game.  The interface is incredibly clunky-- often it's confusing or outright lies about what will happen (cancel, dismiss, buying items, etc).  It was never clear how to use certain abilities and we often lost battles because it wouldn't explain how things would add up once we entered combat (we never figured it out).  It frequently disconnected one player and kept reconnecting him as the wrong player before kicking him again; the CPU sold off his items while he tried to get back in.\nFor the 4.5 hours we spent playing, it was a long slog of fighting the interface for not a lot of fun.  Stick with the physical board game, it's actually functional.

reviewText:
People who like Talisman the board game will like this digital recreation. It's spot on.

If you've never played talisman, it's a mediocre board game that often drags near the end of the game, with punishing mechanics that can wipe hours of play at the drop of a hat. I'd get the expansions and use the alternate endings to reduce the long end game.

That said, I've played this game and the physical version several times and keep coming back. Something about watching your character grow and overcoming challenges is addicting despite the dated board game mechanics.

reviewText:
People who like Talisman the board game will like this digital recreation. It's spot on.

If you've never played talisman, it's a mediocre board game that often drags near the end of the game, with punishing mechanics that can wipe hours of play at the drop of a hat. I'd get the expansions and use the alternate endings to reduce the long end game.

That said, I've played this game and the physical version several times and keep coming back. Something about watching your character grow and overcoming challenges is addicting despite the dated board game mechanics.

reviewText: Not a very fun game unless you enjoy praying to RNGesus. I played my first and last game against the AI to learn how the game works. Got to the crown around turn 60, then spent another 60 turns sitting on that space doing nothing. Once you get to the center you're stuck rolling until you get booted or you kill everyone. Meanwhile, the AI jerked around in the outer ring of tiles healing up at least as must damage I was dealing from the crown.\n\nWhile sitting through this mind-numbing experience I found that you can set house rules" to end the game when someone reaches the crown
date: or to stop healing when someone is at the crown
recommended: but the fact that there are such glaring design flaws in the base game is pretty unforgivable."

reviewText:
Its monoply with combat and no free parking.

This is a digital version of the board game.  You and your opponets roll a dice pick a direction and move that many spaces then draw an encounter card.  some times its helpful but most of the time it screws you over.

Theres also combat where you roll a dice and what your fighting rolls a dice and you add your strength to the dice.  you lose and you lose a life you win you get to keep them as torphy. get enough trophies and you can up your strenght or craft.

and thats really it. your trying to beef your guy up enough to surive the spaces in the center of the board. its long and boring.  the avrage game runs about an hour per player.  you do get a number of characters to choose from each with there own advantages but some are way better than others.  (the assassin is way OP).  you can unlock runes that give you the option of starting with buffs which can speed future games along but its still the same boring game.

on top of that the UI isn't great.  trying to use a card in your inventory is needlessly complicated and spells are a pain in the ♥♥♥ to use.  most of the time you have to queue them a turn ahead of time and then the game auto casts them at the soonest legal moment next turn and there is no way to back out once you've decided to start doing somthing.  there are also things that are suppose to give you the choice of uping  either strength or craft but the game will auto pick which ever stat is highest.

So we have a slow boring game with a dodgey UI.  Pass

reviewText: Awesome game. Truly one of the best board to digital game i've ever had the opportunity to play. The add-ons are completely worth it as well.  Now for the bad news. There have been multiple instances when playing with my group of friends where someone or multiple people will drop connection. SOMETIMES, you can resume game (which is a cool feature) but othertimes it just will not work. It gets really funky. Now, to me, there is nothing worse than spending 2.5 hours on a game with 3 other people and right as it's getting good the multiplayer takes a dump all over and we can't finish the game. The support is also non-existant (thanks Nomad) so don't believe this will change any time soon, but if enough people are buying and playing maybe that will change (I highly doubt it. Wishful thinking maybe). TL;DR: Solo play is worth it at sale price, but mulitplayer is a big risk although it is insanely fun.

reviewText:
This does the board  game version a lot of justice.
The cards and squares are accurate, the art is the same and the gameplay is fluid.
There have been some issues with crashes which I expect to be resolved soon and during the AI or other people turns you are unable to look at other squares of the board to become more familiar, but these issues are very little.
The AI does tend to make some silly choices that most people would try avoid but I imagine this will be patched soon
Overall 4/5

+Accurate when compared to the board game
+Fast and Fluent gameplay
+Soundtrack
+Saves your game

-A Few bugs
-No Tutorial for new players
voteText: 1 of 3 people (33%) found this review helpful

reviewText: I love a great boardgame but let's face it, these cardboard children" - to borrow a line from RPS - can take a LOT of table real estate to play. Talisman is a massive game in its "analog form" and with all of the expansions and four players
date: the setup is considerable and games can be marathons. But that's all good as boardgamers expect that. That said
recommended: Talisman Digital Edition fots nicely on my PC
hoursPlayed: requires mere minutes at most of setup an most importantly
voteText: captures the sheer fun of Talisman
helpfulPercent: Isn't that why we play games
votesHelpful: for fun?\n\nA few negative reviews commented on the woeful AI. But
votesTotal: perhaps these folk are playing the prelude titled Talisman: Prologue. I have found the AI to be pretty good. And let's not forget that Talisman is largely a luck based game. All of the so-called tactics I have seen and heard about the game must still bow to the capriciousness of the deity known as RNG; even an AI like Deep Blue cannot predict the vagaries of dice rolls.\n\nThere are a few issues that linger. One of the most annoying is when an AI opponent draws an event card. Unless you are a speed reader or you know every Talisman card by rote - and with all of the expansions in the physical boardgame there is an insane number of cards
votesFunny:
you won't have time to read what the event is. You have to zoom in on the board section where the event is. The same holds true for other non-spell cards. This has been brought up to the devs but as yet there has been no fix for this.

The digital version allows you to earn runes which grant advatages in gameplay. [AI also collects these as well]. I like the mechanic as it lends a sort of leveling up feeling.

The Dungeon Expansion is next up and I cannot wait for its release! If it is as faithful as the physical version of the game
commentsCount:
it's going to be a blast.

I think that Talisman Digital Edition is a wonderful introduction to the fun world of tabletop boardgaming and it scratches the itch of tabletop boardgamers who want to play without the crazy setup and rather forced solo variants for the physical game found round the interwebz.

This is a STEAL at the price and I would advise buyers to spend a little extra dosh and get The Reaper and Frostmarch expansions as they add considerably to the game.

I hope that more boardgames experience a digital conversion. Are you listening Games Workshop and Fantasy Flight?

EDIT: 18 November. The Dungeon expansion really ramps this game up considerably. The AI can be quite nasty and that's good as Talisman is a cut throat game.

I am hopeful that the devs will release Blood Moon and The Dragon next. These two expansions literally change the game
column16: adding a bit more unpredictability to a game that can punch you in the face already and have you smiling about it.\n\nUPDATE January 15: Ya gota love this developer. With the latest update there are two new free characters. These two are not even present in the physical boardgame but were last seen in the 1986(!) version of Talisman. More achievements plus what seems to be a hint that the Highland expansion is next! This is very cool as it is a one of the big corner expansions!!"
column17: July 1, 2014
column18: true

reviewText: I don't understand how the metascore was so low... then again, i don't use the metascore as a solid guide anyways.  I would recommend this game to folks who are in to fantasty board games. i thought the game was fairly simple and it only took me about two games to fully understand the concept and what the characters do.  i have had a grand time with friends who also purchased this game.  i would not necessarily recommend the game to individuals who want to play by themselves.  some of the matches can last up to 3 or 4 hours and playing by yourself is just not my cup of placenta.  talisman is fair in the sense that it is chance; your battles are similar to that of risk, however you build on your attributes such as strength and craft (magic).  some characters have neat perks to assist you in acquiring the talisman to reach the center of the board.  the characters provide you with a bit of variety and the adventure cards and item cards you get to draw are numerous.  i find the game both amusing and entertaining.  i would recommend this game if you like old school board games i.e. dungeon (from gary gygax in 1980.) hope you cats have fun too! <3

reviewText:
Steam really needs a thumb sideways for games like this.

On one hand the game seems to be a faithful adaptation to the board game (from what people say. Ive never played it) The game is realativly fun and it has an online option.

The other hand though.... I encountered a slew of bugs/glitches which ended in some actions not being counted or moves being skipped. The AI is horrible. They refuse to go into the inner section until they are around 13 in their stat and they make a lot of stupid moves. A mectric ton of dlc that kind of feels like its to much when the base game has very little to offer in terms of chracters/boards/and cards.

If you like the board game and want to play it then im sure you'll have a decent time with it. For everyone else though, I would avoid buying this unless its very cheap or on a humble bundle.

reviewText: Pay no mind to the Metacritic score, those critics reviewed the game when it first came out.  At that time it had a huge number of bugs and other problems, particularly with multiplayer, but those have been entirely rectified.  This is a fantastic adaptation of a great board game.  It takes a long time to play, especially with a lot of players; less time than the actual board game though since you don't have to bother with setting it up or putting it away.  The game itself is quite a lot of fun for any RPG and board game lover.  It's a great value too, especially if you pick it up on sale (and it goes on sale fairly frequently).  The only real downside is that the AI is still terrible, so you're pretty much limited to playing with friends for a worthwhile experience.

reviewText:
Very happy to have this game on pc.  I still own 2 versions of the original board game which I have played countless times.  As such I can confirm the game rules are superbly accurate to the original, making this game a must for all Talisman fans.
On occasion, it can be difficult to use an ability or specific card during your turn (within the time limit given) as the game will not remind or encourage you to check your inventory lists, so you need to pay attention.
This is a rare occurance, however, dependant on character chosen rather than any particular oversight due to the game design.  There are plenty of new characters to purchase as well as three of the original six expansion packs already released.  Dice roll for me is depressingly unlucky (just as it always was for my board games) so i find the gameplay quite difficult.  Animations are colourful and the addition of runestones and customisable rules keeps the game interesting. You can even save your progress on multiple games and come back to them when you want.
I highly recommend this game already and will love it even more when the Timescape expansion is added.

reviewText: Talisman, with all the expansion content enabled, is a very fun game with an expansive, adventurous feel that supports a variety of diverse play styles.  Without the expansion content enabled, it's a much more straightforward and less interesting experience.  The UI could also benefit from some adjustments, as it's sometimes difficult to click spells before the game moves past the point where they're legal to play, and at times you're forced to make a decision without the ability to click around to examine details of the game state... issues which can both be largely mitigated by familiarity and careful attentiveness, but which will hopefully be remedied in the future.\n\nAll of this together makes for a game that's a lot of fun with a bit of investment, but which does not make a good first impression.  I almost asked for a refund, but I'm very glad I didn't.

reviewText: Talisman: Digital Edition is a faithful update to the old school Games-Workshop Talisman board game.  The game is actually based on a newer iteration by Fantasy Flight games however much of the original feel is still there.  The digital implementation of the game features an intuitive interface, crisp artwork, and balance improvements that don’t allow a Chaos Warrior to run rampant across your game board and on top of competing players.  The only real downside is that the AI is not very good and doesn’t try to win the game –however the game plays well in multiplayer and is really a blast.  If you want to play an old school early 1990’s board game online, love games workshop, or just want to turn your buddies into a toad and curb stomp them . . . this game is for you!

reviewText:
Love this game. Love it!

I'm a board game/TTRPG junkie (multi-time Gen Con attendee). There's a ton of content here, and the game is fun and challenging at the same time. It's nice to be able to just jump into the digital edition without setup, and even with some AI that's not TOO bad. It does make a few boneheaded mistakes though.

For instance I usually play with random characters against 3 AI. I had the Troll. I killed one of the other characters and forgot to loot ALL the items (my own fault, hit the button to quick) and the Devil's Minion CPU player swooped in and grabbed it all including the follower that reduces the Peril of Plane's requirements by 1 die. OMG.

The Devil's Minion made to the the Crown of Command, because he made it there so early he only had 5 STR and 6 CRA. I got EXTREMELY lucky and grabbed the poltergiest as a follower on the right side of the outer region of the board. Along there was The healer with 2 free heals " (thankfully I got turned to Good along the way!) and "The Shrine"
date: next to them was the Forest. So since I could only move one space it was great that I could keep moving back and forth between these spaces healing myself and trying to bump up my craft at the Forest. I also had spells of one Counterspell
hoursPlayed: and one Temporal Warp. I was going to use the Temporal Warp when I finally started making my run to the Crown! I made a huge mistake by going into the Village and not realizing it ditched the Poltergiest! OH NO!\n\nSince I had 10 STR and 5 CRA
voteText: I decided to make a run for it. The Devil's Minion rolled BADLY on quite a few Crown spells. I luckily made my way all the way to the Crown with 11 STR from figting one monster along the way and cashing some in.\n\nSo the Devil's Minion had 5 lives
helpfulPercent: I had 4. But I definitely had the upper hand from a mathematical standpoint. So what does the Devil's Minion do when he fights me
votesHelpful: he picks STR!! WHAT IN THE. I was afraid it was going to be a race to 0 to see who could roll luck (he COULDN'T beat me in STR 11 vs 5
votesTotal: but he had a chance in CRA 5 vs 6). So I whittled him down to 1 health
votesFunny: and THEN he finally lets loose with a CRA attack and actually wins. I beat him the next turn.\n\nThis is what I mean by the AI makes some poor decisions. What should have been a nail-biter
commentsCount: ended up being a big WHA? What is he doing?!\n\nStill love the game!!"

reviewText:
If you like board games then this game is great.  You'll want to get DLC at least to Dungeon to make it more replayable.  You do not need humans to play and the AI isn't that bad, except for their use of spells.  Spells aren't utilized very well by AI.  It will take time to learn the When can I cast this system."  Spells do not have a natural or intuitive system for casting.  Even after 10-15 games you can still not cast them at right times always.

Lots of options for which DLC to use each game and what parts of each can be used.

Know games can take 30 minutes to 3 hours to win.  What character you play and what cards you and the others get make a huge difference in the time involved."

reviewText: This game is probably a bit coloured by nostalgia for me, as it was a fond summer event to meet my cousin that had this game and we had a lot of fun with it, even without any expansions. This game is a very faitfull adaptation, and the expansions have never been more accessible. They are doing hot-seat right with regard to hidden cards. And a great set of houserules avaliable. If you are not familiar with talisman, it is a very laid-back game where the focus is more on experiencing stuff than actually making any big decissions that matter. This newer version include a faith point system that older versions didn't have, that somewhat alievates the otherwise a bit snakes and ladders" feel the game might get when you are used to it. So recomended if you want a easy somewhat competitative game with fantasy theme (the theme is strong with this one). If you want more challenging decissionmaking there are probably better options."

reviewText: Okay, right off the bat, this is an awesome game to play! So much fun to level up your character, gaining strength and craft to fight enemies with. The object of the game is to reach the crown of command" in the center of the board. However this is not so simple. You will have to go on different quests throughout the game to gain an object known as a "Talisman" to get the various places on the board. You will need one as you travel from the middle region of the board to the center region. However many things could happen between getting one and getting through to the center region. A player could fight you and kill you. A witch
date: bear or demon could spawn on you and destroy powerful or useful items you're carrying. The worst? Being turned into a toad. This is where all your items are dropped in the space you have turned into the toad. While playing as a toad
recommended: other players can pick up your items. It's a very challenging game and extremely time consuming. The 8 hours i have played.. 6 of them is just one full game of talisman
hoursPlayed: where unfortunately i did not win! I have the actual board game too and the digital version helped me learn it better as it gives you tutorials on your playthrough. Of course these can be turned off! If you are a fan of fantasy

reviewText:
This is a faithful recreation of a board game which involves running in circles and cursing dice rolls.

Its enjoyable but there are several aspects which may result in depression or rage.

Game summery:
- Choose a fantasy class (with stats and powers).
- Move randomly around the board and deal with events and other players.
- Increase your strength and/or craft skills.
- Fight your way to the center of the board.
- Patiently wait until everyone else dies. This can be reduced by changing the game options.

Be warned, this game contains:
- My average game length is 1-2 hours, but it can be much longer.
- Devastating random events. A single die roll MAY (and will) destroy you.
- Horribly broken AI (which gives you a fighting chance of victory).
- Waiting on AI turns (sometimes their turns are longer than your own).
- Predetermined dice rolls (no restarting to cheat against the AI).
- Lots of Confirm" buttons when several could be replaced by having an "undo" button instead.
- No "auto play" option for times when there is no choice involved.
- Massive amounts of pay DLC.

I recommend it
date: but its certainly not for everyone!"

reviewText:
Talisman is wonderful. A tabletop board game brought to us digitally.

HOWEVER,

the game isn't just about strategy. The luck of the roll has it's play here. But no more so than it would any other board game like Monopoly. Some people don't like this.

I find myself entertained for hours at a time. Playing with friends either online or as a local game with a couple AI's is just as fun. All we do is pass the mouse back and forth!

It's addicting, and I LOVE IT.

10/10
